model.name: Rome
model.description: They called it *urbs kaput mundi*—the city at the center of the world. And while this gorgeous tumble of ancient and Renaissance buildings may have ceded that title centuries ago, it’s still endlessly fascinating. Its tastemakers retrofit their own inimitable takes on being Roman—whether it’s the elevation of rib-sticking pastas at Roscioli, or the whimsical jewels designed by Delfina Delettrez—into its glorious, timeless maze. All you need to do to find beauty, inspiration, and something seriously delicious to eat is walk out the door of your hotel. (Did we mention it has some killer hotels, too?).

model.dontMiss:
###Visit##


[#activity: /activities/53eae58fdd4d6a0b75efc796]|||
Go modern at one of Rome's most beautiful and historic palazzi. The [Galleria Borghese](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/borghese-gallery) is showing British artist Mat Collishaw's Black Mirror through January 11, 2015.  The exhibition is inspired by the broodingly dark backgrounds of the Caravaggio paintings found in the museum. 
|||


###Play##


[#activity: /activities/5494468944d4f45926eaff1e]|||
Italy's cultural minister has announced plans to open the [Colosseum](
http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/colloseum) as a space to perform cultural and music events. Stay tuned--but don't hold your breath for gladiator re-enactors. This promises to be more high-brow.
|||


###See###


[#activity: /activities/53eae58fdd4d6a0b75efc798]|||
“Bellissima: Italy and High Fashion, 1945–1968,” an exhibition of famous Italian fashion designers such as Salvatore Ferragamo, Emilio Pucci, Mila Schön, and Valentino opens at the [MAXXI](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/maxxi) National Museum of XXI Century Arts designed by Zaha Hadid. Through May 3, 2015. 
|||

###Explore##


[#activity: /activities/54944c1d44d4f45926eb00dc]|||
See the beautiful Renaissance portraits by artist Hans Memling (c.1430-1494) at the [Scuderie del Quirinale](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/scuderie-del-quirinale) through January 18th. The show examines the artist's extensive popularity in Italy during his lifetime. 
|||


###FYI##
Starting December 14th, Rome's Fiumicino main airport will be linked by high-speed train to Venice. The [Frecciargento (Silver Arrow) trains](http://www.trenitalia.com/) will also serve central Rome, Florence, Bologna, and Padua.

fields.name: Amy Plitt
fields.shortBio: Amy Plitt is the digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Amy Plitt is a Brooklyn-based writer and digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.* She has written for such publications as *Rolling Stone,* the A.V. Club, *Foam*, Made Man, *Mental Floss*, and *Time Out New York*, where she was a staff editor. She's also the author of *[Subway Adventure Guide: New York City](http://www.triumphbooks.com/subway-adventure-guide--new-york-city-products-9781629370774.php?page_id=21)* (Triumph Books), a guidebook about the ends of New York City's subway lines. When she travels, she's on the lookout for excellent local beers, weird museums, and nerdy historical sites.

fields.name: Maria Shollenbarger
fields.shortBio: London-based contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Born and raised in Los Angeles and educated in New England and Italy, Maria Shollenbarger now calls East London home. She worked at *InStyle*and *Travel + Leisure,* among others, before joining *Condé Nast Traveler* in October 2013. She is the Travel Editor for *How To Spend It,* the luxury supplement to the Financial Times.

featuredPlays.name: Borghese Gallery
featuredPlays.description: A must-visit right up there with the Vatican, Roman Forum, and Colosseum, this former home of the aristocratic Borghese family houses one of the world's most impressive 17th-century sculpture collections—not least of all Bernini's Apollo and Daphne—and more than its fare share of Baroque paintings, too, nearly all collected by the family. Book ahead online to secure a spot for one of the two-hour-long viewing times throughout the day, and spend some time after your visit exploring the Borghese Gardens, one of the city's largest public parks.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Check out the exquisite art, then spend some time wandering the gorgeous surrounding gardens.

featuredPlays.name: Galleria Doria Pamphilj
featuredPlays.description: The Galleria Doria Pamphilj is a near-overdose art high: packed densely with 17th-century Flemish, Italian, English and Spanish masters (Velazquez’s famous portrait of Innocent X  – yes, he was a Doria-Pamphilj – hangs here), it also gives you a window into how the palazzo’d half lives: the private apartments, in which the family still resides, are open to the public on certain days of the week.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: View the 17th-century art, then peek at the private apartments where the family still lives.

featuredPlays.name: Palazzo Colonna
featuredPlays.description: Until recently, you had to be a VIP to access the private galleries of the Palazzo Colonna, one of the most impressive private homes in the city (Colonnas have lived here for 450 years; they’ve been Roman aristocracy for 800). It’s now open to the public, and stuffed with an artistic patrimony that anywhere else would earn it its own museum wing: Caracci, Bronzino, Tintoretto, and Veronese are just a few of the all-stars whose work graces the ornate spaces. Have your hotel concierge ahead for a private tour on Saturday.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: One of the city's grandest—and most art-filled—private homes, which is finally open to the public.

featuredPlays.name: Scooteroma Tours
featuredPlays.description: You know you want to ride around the Eternal City on a vintage Vespa like Gregory Peck did in *Roman Holiday* (and you know your teenager does). The folks at Scooteroma Tours know too. You can simply explore the *centro storico* with a guide, or you can theme a four-hour excursion: taste pastries in Trastevere or cheese in the ghetto, for instance, or follow the trail of the film *La Grande Bellezza*. They also do Fiat 500, “ape” (a three-wheeled truck like a tuk-tuk) and bicycle tours. Tours are all private and customized, so email Scooteroma to set yours up.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Explore the city like a (super chic) local: by tooling around on a vintage Vespa.

featuredShops.name: Fleur
featuredShops.description: This concept shop is a den of chic, offering art, fashion, and design books; candles and home fragrances; Deco- and midcentury-inspired furniture and lighting; women's fashion from a handful of sought-after international labels; a petite tea house and an oyster bar are in the back, for those looking to take a break from shopping.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Rome’s answer to Colette, with clothing by Yigal Azrouel, candles by DL&Co., and an oyster bar.

featuredShops.name: Saddlers Union
featuredShops.description: Taken over by a former public relations gal, this leather specialist recently received a much-needed reboot. Today, the brand continues to work with top artisans to create its signature bucket and weekend bags and briefcases, as well as new designs, in a variety of leathers and exotic skins.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Visit this newly renovated, decades old leather specialist for sleek bucket bags and briefcases.

featuredShops.name: Delfina Delettrez
featuredShops.description: A scion of high fashion's Fendi family, the designer behind this eponymous, green-walled, bijoux jewellery shop creates decidedly modern rings, necklaces, bracelets, and earrings. The looks range from brightly colored, high-mod geometric bracelets to surreal pieces incorporating a Dali-esque eye motif rendered in previous and semi-precious stones and metals. Guys will find a smattering of cufflinks.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Look like a street-style star in these fashion-forward pieces for fingers, neck, wrists, and ears.

featuredShops.description: This luxury vintage store is the place where can find an impeccable Chanel dress that was only worn once or a pair of gloves that might have belonged to a countess. It feels like you're digging through your most glamorous friend's closet.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Designer finds fill the racks at this vintage shop, down the street from the flagship Miu Miu store.
featuredShops.name: Lesley

stay.hed: The 50 Best Hotels in Italy: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
stay.dek: Luxury, history, style—there's no place like Italy. And there are no places in Italy like these 50 amazing hotels, named the best by our Condé Nast Traveler readers. ([View as list](http://www.cntraveler.com/readers-choice-awards/2014/europe/best-hotels-in-italy-readers-choice-awards-2014).)
stay.seoTitle: The Best Hotels in Italy: Florence, Portofino, Rome, Lake Como, & More
stay.seoDescription: Condé Nast Traveler Readers choose the 50 best hotels in Italy in our 2014 poll.
stay.socialDescription: Luxury, history, style—there's no place like Italy. And there are no places in Italy like these 50 amazing hotels, named the best by our Condé Nast Traveler readers.

items.title: [50. Boscolo Venezia](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/venice/boscolo-venezia)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 81.096

Its location away from the Grand Canal, in a relatively quiet part of Cannaregio, is a good thing: being far from the crowds means an infinitely more peaceful experience. In a city famous for water, the hotel's amazing, 21,000 square foot garden offers a unique terra firma touch. Plus, a free shuttle service will get you to St. Mark's and other attractions daily.

items.title: [49. Westin Europa & Regina, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/venice/westin-europa-and-regina)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.100

Comprising of five interconnected palazzi—it is the amalgamation of the former Hotel Britannia and Hotel Regina—this hotel still manages to feel secluded despite its size and renown. It’s tucked away inside a leafy, hidden courtyard, and guests arrive via a private jetty on the Grand Canal. Its 185 guest rooms are Venetian-inspired, many with private terraces and views over the Canal.

items.title: [48. Luna Hotel Baglioni, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/luna-hotel-baglioni--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.140

This historic, 68-room hotel in the heart of the city is housed in an aristocratic Venetian palace dating back to 1118. Though it’s been through countless transformations over the years, it still brims with original details: ceiling frescoes, ornate stucco walls, Murano chandeliers and antique gold fixtures. Its restaurant, Canova, has won multiple awards for its seasonal, traditional Italian cuisine.

items.title: [47. Capri Palace Hotel & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/anacapri/capri-palace-hotel---spa)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.143

Located in tranquil, scenic Anacapri—away from the bustle of Capri town—this hotel is a place to relax rather than be seen. Guests can enjoy spa treatments at the world famous Capri Beauty Farm, and lavish dinners at the two-Michelin starred restaurant, L’Olivo. Best of all, Il Riccio, the hotel’s own beach club and restaurant by the Blue Grotto, offers the prettiest sunset views on the island.

items.title: [46. Grand Hotel Majestic, Lake Maggiore](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/lake-maggiore/grand-hotel-majestic)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.169

The aptly-named Grand Hotel Majestic lives up to to the hype with its Belle Epoque splendor, secluded English-style gardens, private beach and jetty on Lake Maggiore. All 80 rooms are decorated in a classical style with lush fabrics, antique furnishings and chandeliers. Ask for a water view—even some of the more basic rooms have them.

items.title: [45. Londra Palace, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/londra-palace--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.489

This neoclassical hotel is situated by Piazza San Marco along the Riva degli Schiavoni, overlooking the Lagoon. Each of its 53 rooms  is thoughtfully decorated with silk brocade walls and Biedermeier furniture. Its popular Do Leoni restaurant serves Classic Venetian fare using fresh ingredients bought from the Rialto Market daily; evening cocktails are served at its wood bar or out on the terrace.

items.title: [44. Westin Excelsior, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/westin-excelsior--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.525

Located mere steps from the Duomo and the Piazza della Signoria, the Westin occupies one of Florence’s most central locations. Inside, you’ll find a fusion of Tuscan, Empire, and Florentine design influences with marble floors, stained glass, tapestries, and frescoes. Se.Sto on Arno, the hotel’s glass-encased rooftop restaurant, offers five-star Mediterranean cuisine, a selection of over 300 wines, and 360 degree views over Florence and the River Arno.

items.title: [43. Hotel Raphaël, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/rome/hotel-rapha-l)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.646

With its ivy-covered facade, Mirò-heavy art collection, and Richard Meier-designed suites, it’s obvious that the Raphaël is one classy hotel. Its rooms are sleek rather than flashy or opulent, with a mix of modern and traditional details. Its famous, multi-tired rooftop terrace boasts unmatched views over the Pantheon, Palazzo del Quirinale, Piazza di Spagna and beyond.

items.title: [42. Hotel Santa Caterina, Amalfi](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/pontone/hotel-santa-caterina--amalfi)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.762

Beauty greets you at every turn at this 9th century, Liberty-style hotel: terraces are planted with citrus groves and flower gardens, guest rooms have hand-painted tile floors and colorful silk draperies. Lapis lazuli floors and vine-covered arches accent the open-air Ristorante Al Mare by the pool. The honeymoon suites are the highlight here—they feature sunken jacuzzi tubs overlooking the ocean.

items.title: [41. Grand Hotel Excelsior Vittoria, Sorrento](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/sorrento/grand-hotel-excelsior-vittoria--sorrento)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.908

This 1834 family-owned property is located in Sorrento’s bustling historic center, yet feels like a private, leafy oasis. Rooms are designed in styles ranging from Pompeian to Victorian, with trompe l’oeil walls, parquet floors, and gilded mirrors. Terrazza Bosquet serves Neapolitan dishes using ingredients from the hotel's own garden; there’s also a famous terrace bar overlooking the Gulf of Naples and Mount Vesuvius.

items.title: [40. Il San Pietro di Positano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/vettica-maggiore/il-san-pietro-di-positano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.038

From a distance, Il San Pietro appears as if it’s been hewn into the craggy cliff on which it rests. Each of its rooms has its own private terrace and boasts a picturesque view over the Bay of Positano. An elevator built into the rocks leads guests down to a private beach and to the dreamy Carlino restaurant.

items.title: [39. Il Falconiere, Cortona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/cortona/il-falconiere--cortona--tuscany)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.750

Originally only a restaurant, this 17th century villa located outside Cortona has been owned and managed by the same family since 1860. It now features 29 acres of landscaped gardens, vineyards and olive groves, and naturally, there’s an on-site winery that’s open daily for tastings. Rooms are rustic chic, and decorated with a mix of antiques and traditional textiles.

items.title: [38. Ca' Sagredo Hotel, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/ca-sagredo-hotel--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.770

Ca' Sagredo looks more like a palace than a hotel with its marble staircases, wall friezes, gilded ceilings and 42 deeply posh guest rooms. Half of it is actually a museum, highlighting the paintings of 17th and 18th-century artists like Sebastiano Ricci and Giambattista Tiepolo. Don’t miss dinner at the scenic L’Alcova restaurant, where ingredients are bought daily at the Rialto Market across the street.

items.title: [37. Hotel Buca di Bacco, Positano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/positano/hotel-buca-di-bacco--positano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.869

Framed by rocky hills on the sandy shores of Spiaggia Grande, this hotel makes for the perfect Positano beach getaway—the ocean is literally steps from your door. Rooms are understated, but the spectacular Tyrrhenian sea views make up for it. The Buca di Bacco restaurant, which serves up innovative Amalfi Coast-inspired cuisine, is locally-loved.

items.title: [36. Le Sirenuse, Positano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/positano/le-sirenuse--positano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.872

This legendary Amalfi Coast hotel is known for its impeccable, Moorish baroque style: whitewashed walls, vaulted ceilings, and mosaic-tiled rooms filled with museum-worthy antiques. The pool terrace, decorated with lemon trees and flowers, is equally picturesque. Small, thoughtful touches like cocktails served in handblown Murano glasses make this hotel extra special.

items.title: [35. Hassler Roma](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/quartiere-monte-sacro/hassler--rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.941

Built at the top of the Spanish Steps in 1885, the Hassler is considered one of the city’s most iconic properties and is almost as photographed as the steps themselves. Inside, you’ll find elegant rooms decorated with lush silk draperies, Venetian lamps, Limoges porcelain, and velvet headboards. The sixth-floor restaurant, Imàgo, serves up excellent regional cuisine with panoramic Eternal City views.

items.title: [34. Grand Hotel des Iles Borromees, Lake Maggiore](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/lake-maggiore/grand-hotel-des-iles-borromees)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.011

This hotel is grand by name and nature, from its ornate Art Nouveau architecture to its lush, sculpture-adorned gardens. Its corridors are lined with paintings, tapestries, and statues, and each of its 179 rooms and suites boast views over Lake Maggiore or the distant Alps. Some might say it’s borderline ostentatious, but we think that’s what makes it so fabulous.

items.title: [33. Belmond Grand Hotel Timeo, Taormina, Sicily](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/taormina/grand-hotel-timeo--taormina)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.127

This villa-style hotel is said to have been the select escape of aristocrats and Hollywood royals like Catherine Deneuve and Robert De Niro. Not that we’re surprised—it’s highly secluded, perched high in the rocky hills on the eastern coast of Sicily, offering the island’s finest vistas. Inside, there are 70 Sicilian Baroque-style rooms with private terraces overlooking the Bay of Naxos, the ancient Greek Theatre, and Mount Etna.

items.title: [32. Hotel Lungarno, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/hotel-lungarno--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.229

Unlike many five-star hotels in the area, the Hotel Lungarno feels understatedly and effortlessly stylish—it is, after all, owned by the family of designer Salvatore Ferragamo. Its bright, airy rooms are decorated in clean yellow and ivory tones and feature picture-perfect vistas over the Ponte Vecchio and River Arno. Keep your eyes peeled for its impressive art collection, featuring works by Picasso and Cocteau.

items.title: [31. Hotel de Russie, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/vatican-city/hotel-de-russie--rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.633

Located between the Spanish Steps and Piazza del Popolo, the 89-room Hotel de Russie is in the center of the action—though you wouldn’t know it from the inside. From its quiet courtyard garden to a relaxing five-star spa (featuring sauna and hammam), the entire place simply breathes tranquility. The hotel's restaurant, Le Jardin de Russie, is set in a “secret garden” and specializes in traditional Roman seafood dishes.

items.title: [30. St. Regis Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/quartiere-monte-sacro/st--regis-rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.703

The St. Regis is in many ways fabulous, but its trump card is its unmatched attention to detail. From stylish touches like Murano glass lamps and painted frescoes, to the original artwork by Luca Pignatelli, Ubaldo Bartolini and Paolo Fiorentino, each of its 138 guest rooms and 23 suites feel unique and personal. The hotel’s Le Grand bar is considered by many as Rome’s best; order their signature Mediterranean Bloody Mary and decide for yourself.

items.title: [29. Palazzo Victoria, Verona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/verona/palazzo-victoria)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.752

Just a short stroll from Castelvecchi Castle, Casa di Giulietta (Juliet’s house) and Porta Borsari, this 14th century palace-turned-hotel couldn’t have been built in a more beautiful or historical location. Its 71 guest rooms match the splendor of its surrounds, featuring sumptuous decor, original frescoes and marble soaking tubs. At the hotel restaurant, Borsari 36, guests can admire the Roman remains beneath them through Plexiglass inserts while enjoying seasonal Venetian cuisine.

items.title: [28. St. Regis Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/st--regis-florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.251

The St. Regis is considered one of Florence’s most treasured structures, and it’s no wonder—the majestic 14th century palazzo was designed by the legendary Renaissance architect Filippo Brunelleschi himself. Each of its 80 guest rooms and 19 suites boast posh Florentine decor; some even offer step-out balconies and views over the River Arno. Its wine cellar, Cantinetta, is set inside a medieval cave, features over 300 wines, and is open for daily tastings.

items.title: [27. BAUERs Il Palazzo, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/bauer-il-palazzo--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.514

This hotel’s opulent, gothic-style facade teases passersby with a small glimpse of the grandeur that lies within. There are dripping Murano glass chandeliers hanging from trompe l'oeil ceilings, gilded mirrors set against silk-lined walls, 18th-century Venetian furnishings—no luxury has been spared here. Many of its 38 guest rooms and 34 suites offer panoramic vistas over the Grand Canal, where there’s a private dock for guests making trips to the nearby Palladio Spa.

items.title: [27. Bauers Il Palazzo, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/bauer-il-palazzo--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.514

This hotel’s opulent, gothic-style facade teases passersby with a small glimpse of the grandeur that lies within. There are dripping Murano glass chandeliers hanging from trompe l'oeil ceilings, gilded mirrors set against silk-lined walls, 18th-century Venetian furnishings—no luxury has been spared here. Many of its 38 guest rooms and 34 suites offer panoramic vistas over the Grand Canal, where there’s a private dock for guests making trips to the nearby Bauer Palladio Spa.

items.title: [26. Hotel Helvetia & Bristol, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/hotel-helvetia---bristol--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.940

Set in a historic palazzo mere steps from the Duomo, Ponte Vecchio, and Via Tornabuoni, the Helvetia might just be the best-placed hotel in all of Florence. In addition to magnificent city views, all 67 of its rooms are lavishly adorned with silk brocade fabrics, handpicked antique furniture, 17th-century Florentine paintings, and crystal chandeliers. If that weren’t enough, there’s also an excellent restaurant onsite specializing in authentic Tuscan cuisine.

items.title: [25. Belmond Hotel Splendido & Splendido Mare, Portofino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/santa-margherita-ligure/hotel-splendido---splendido-mare--portofino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.972

The setting lives up to the name at this two-building property. One part of the hotel, on a hillside, is a 16th-century former monastery once attacked by Saracen pirates; the Mare half is on the town's piazzetta by the lively harbor. Rooms mostly come with balconies; some offer panoramic views of Portofino cove. Don’t miss the heated saltwater pool. La Terrazza specializes in local seafood dishes.

items.title: [24. Grand Hotel Villa Serbelloni, Lake Como](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/bellagio/grand-hotel-villa-serbelloni--lake-como)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.126

Although Lake Como can feel ultra-private and secluded,  the Grand Hotel Villa Serbelloni makes it feel like the center of the world. The hotel offers regular excursions to Bergamo, Lugano, Saint Moritz, and the Borromean Islands, but it’s also worth staying put in the evenings to take in the nightly live music in the lounge or a cleansing visit to the sauna.

items.title: [23. Grand Hotel Tremezzo, Lake Como](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/lake-como/grand-hotel-tremezzo--lake-como)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.179

This 80-room, 12-suite Art Nouveau-style hotel has panoramic windows that offer 360-degree views of Lake Como. But you will be so busy taking in the three swimming pools, six restaurants and cafes, and exclusive golf course that you might not have time to stalk George Clooney.

items.title: [22. Jumeirah Grand Hotel Via Veneto, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/rome/jumeirah-grand-hotel-via-veneto)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.190

Via Veneto was once the city’s party thoroughfare immortalized in some of Fellini's classic films, but nowadays it’s a much more tame affair - lined with embassies and private palazzi. This hotel makes a great launch pad into the city, but offerings like a roof terrace and plenty of nooks to hide away in, creates a nice sense of intimacy as well.

items.title: [21. Grand Hotel Villa Cora, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/grand-hotel-villa-cora)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.250

A wedding gift from a baron to his lucky bride, this luxurious 19th century property continues to feel like a private home, albeit one with 46-rooms kitted out with neoclassical treasures. Despite being on the outskirts of town, a complimentary shuttle bus makes it easy to access the city center.

items.title: [20. Grand Hotel Continental, Siena](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/sienna/grand-hotel-continental--siena--tuscany)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.416

Located in the heart of Siena, near the city’s famed Campo, this historic property comes with plenty of original grand details—frescos, period artwork, and a 17th century ballroom—alongside more modern amenities. Don’t miss the stylish wine bar.

items.title: [19. Four Seasons Hotel Milano](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/milan/four-seasons-hotel-milano)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.529

Close to the city’s legendary shopping area,  Montenapoleone, this property makes an excellent choice for business travelers and families with younger kids in tow, with amenities for both, and the kind of warm but professional service that the northern city can sometimes lack.

items.title: [18. Park Hatt Milan](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/milan/park-hyatt-milan)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.537

If you need a break from the somewhat chintzy and overblown style of some other Milanese favorites you've come to the right place. Here, clean lines and soothing colors create a cocooning effect and the multi-lingual staff exemplifies the kind of spot-on service the brand has made famous worldwide.

items.title: [17. Tuscany Firenze](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/florence/tuscany-firenze)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.657

A member of the Starhotels group, the Tuscany Firenze is located in the business district of northern Florence near the airport. What this modern hotel may lack in local charm it more than makes up for as an excellent, affordable option for early morning flight arrivals or departures - including good food at Assaggi restaurant and a cozy, leather armchair-filled bar.

items.title: [16. Belmond Villa San Michele, Fiesole-Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/fiesole/villa-san-michele--fiesole)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.836

Sitting up in the hills of Florence’s Fiesole, this former monastery remains one of Italy’s most legendary hotels mainly because of the feeling of being in its own idyllic world floating above the Renaissance city, with landscaped gardens, an excellent cooking school, and pool. One could almost forget all the attractions right outside the gates.

items.title: [15. Belmond Hotel Cipriani, Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/lido/hotel-cipriani--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.856

This legendary property on Venice’s Giudecca continues to draw A-listers for its Olympic size pool, old school white glove service, and romantic gardens that seem a million miles from the throngs in Saint Mark’s Square (but it’s only a short boat away). Rooms in the main building recently received a necessary update to restore them to their former glory.

items.title: [14. Grand Hotel Convento di Amalfi](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/amalfi/grand-hotel-convento-di-amalfi)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.951

Perched on top of a cliff facing the sea, one can’t help but be a bit jealous of the nuns who once called this home. But of course they didn’t have the same amenities—a pool overlooking the water, the restaurant Dei Cappucini with its sweeping views, a hammam and gym.

items.title: [13. JK Place, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/j--k--place--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.037

The model for an intimate boutique hotel, this 20-room hideaway sits on the beautiful piazza of Santa Maria Novella with an outdoor terrace facing the famed church, a cozy library with a fireplace, and incredibly chic rooms kitted out by famed Italian designer Michele Bonan.

items.title: [12. Belmond Hotel Caruso, Ravello](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/ravello/hotel-caruso--ravello)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.331

This eleventh-century villa sits high above the town of Ravello overlooking the vertiginous Amalfi Coast. Should you feel like coming down from the heights, there’s plenty to see and do here: the hotel will take you to Positano or Pompeii via its boat, Ercole (Italian for “Hercules”) or you can sign up for a three-hour guided Vespa tour of the town by night. A full restoration transformed this Moorish-influenced palazzo into a property as dazzling as its location. The frescoes burst with color, the gardens are a sensory bonanza, and the extraordinary infinity pool makes it seem as if you could float out to the turquoise sea a thousand feet below. Add to all this a stunning terrace restaurant and superb service and it’s hard to imagine leaving.

items.title: [12. Belmond Hotel Caruso, Ravello](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/ravello/hotel-caruso--ravello)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.331

This eleventh-century villa sits high above the town of Ravello overlooking the vertiginous Amalfi Coast. Should you feel like coming down from the heights, there’s plenty to see and do here: the hotel will take you to Positano or Pompeii via its boat, Ercole (Italian for “Hercules”) or you can sign up for a three-hour guided Vespa tour of the town by night.

items.title: [11. Capri Hotel Caesar Augustus](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/anacapri/capri-hotel-caesar-augustus)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.619

Location location location. Sitting 1000-feet up over the Bay of Naples, the views from this former mansion are stupendous from every vantage point, particularly from the spectacular bi-level infinity pool. (NB: not the best choice for kids in tow because of strict hours at said pool and lots of steps.)

items.title: [10. Four Seasons Hotel Firenze](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/florence/four-seasons-hotel-firenze--florence)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 88.756

One of the most beautiful properties in Italy—with two historic buildings linked by the largest private garden in Florence—comes with impeccable service, wonderful amenities including a spa and pool, and an atmosphere that feels like an oasis after the tourist mayhem of the city center.

items.title: [9. Aldrovandi Villa Borghese, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/parioli/aldrovandi-villa-borghese--rome)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 88.983

Surrounded by one of Rome’s most picturesque of parks near the recently restored Borghese Museum, the Aldrovandi comes with a two-Michelin starred restaurant, a brand new spa and pool, and bikes to tool around the Eternal City.

items.title: [8. San Domenico Palace Hotel, Sicily](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/catania/san-domenico-palace-hotel--taormina)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 89.524

Formerly a 15th-century monastery, this hotel now doesn’t seem to have a problem embracing vice. There are two fully-stocked bars, including one next to the pool, three restaurants, and lush gardens with plenty of hidden corners that lovers can sequester themselves in complete privacy. Set on the slopes of Mount Etna overlooking the Ionian Sea, rooms are converted monk's cells flanking long, arched corridors (some with private terraces).

items.title: [7. Hotel Splendide Royal, Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/rome/hotel-splendide-royal)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 89.796

Close to many of the city’s musts—The Spanish Steps, Villa Borgese, and Piazza del Popolo—the Splendide is the kind of address that makes you feel like you are living at a nobleman’s home. This 19th-century palace is lavishly decorated - marble floors, Murano chandeliers, gilt mirrors, and rooms (many with terraces) overlooking greenery. The Mirabelle restaurant, under the guidance of chef Bruno Borghesi, serves modern Mediterranean cuisine with sweeping city views.

items.title: [6. Castello Banfi il Borgo, Tuscany](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/poggio-alle-mura/castello-banfi-il-borgo--montalcino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 90.476

In many ways the Banfi vineyard put Tuscany’s priceless Brunello on the oenophile map. Now you can also appreciate the hospitality of the estate with its castle digs, two restaurants, and of course, tastings of their vintages.

items.title: [5. The Gritti Palace (Luxury Collection), Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/roma/hotel-gritti-palace--venice)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 90.507

When young men and women used to travel through Europe on their Grand Tour, Venice was a popular stop along the way. Keeping that aesthetic in mind, the Gritti Palace – which recently underwent a $50 million renovation – features suites inspired by famous guests like Ernest Hemingway and Somerset Maugham, and an elegant rooftop bar where guests can mingle while sipping heady cocktails.

items.title: [4. Grand Hotel Miramare, Santa Margherita Ligure](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/santa-margherita-ligure/grand-hotel-miramare--portofino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 91.675

This 1903, Art Nouveau hotel’s crisp white and blue exterior offsets the Genoan landscape, but the real jewel is the garden filled with camellias, oleander, cedar, and fragrant lavender. Rooms and suites (some with balconies with views of the Golfo del Tiguillo or park) are calming and elegant. Every spring, the community holds a welcoming festival for warmer weather complete with bonfires, fireworks, and – best of all – pancakes.

items.title: [3. Palazzo Avino, Ravello](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/castiglione-di-ravello/palazzo-avino--formerly-palazzo-sasso---ravello)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 95.089

Formerly the Palazzo Sasso, this Amalfi Coast jewel continues to shine with some of the most gorgeous sea views in Italy (best enjoyed from the twin Jacuzzis), period pieces from the 17th century, and a Michelin-starred restaurant. Another draw? The property’s proximity to Ravello, arguably this coast’s most charming town.

items.title: [2. Castello di Casole, Tuscany](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/casole-d-elsa/castello-di-casole--casole-d-elsa)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 95.332

This 4200-acre estate outside Siena is a blend of ancient and modern, with big-screen TVs, iPod docking stations, and rain showers located inside a restored fifteenth-century castle and surrounding buildings. The estate still produces its own olive oils and wine and offers in-season wild boar hunting expeditions.

items.title: [1. Il Salviatino, Fiesole-Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/fiesole/il-salviatino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 95.500

A hideaway in Florence’s suburban Fiesole neighborhood, this historic villa includes 12-acres of landscaped gardens, a spa, and beautifully restored rooms with original marble floors and frescos, alongside custom king beds and deep soaking tubs. If you want to splurge, go for one of the penthouses, one of Kate Moss’s preferred crash pads.

items.title: 50. Boscolo Venezia
items.caption: Readers' Rating

Ring the bell at this nondescript spot, and then eat whatever the owner's wife has prepared.
Enjoy seasonal cooking with an ultra-modern touch at this spacious former mill turned restaurant.
At this family-run shop near the Palazzo Borghese, lampshades are elevated to an art form.
Find handmade gold jewelry on Via dell'Orso, where some of Rome's few craftsmen remain.
Find the finest selection of meats, cheeses, and wine at this deli in Testaccio.

items.dek: Expect charmingly gruff service and excellent cacio e pepe at this nearly 80-year-old institution.
Choose family-friendly options at this spot, from pizzas (both Neopolitan and Roman) to burgers.
The meatballs are legendary at this spot, which is built into the side of a mountain.
The best place in Rome for true, outrageously good Sicilian cannoli is in the Testaccio Market.
Explore this open-air market, which has stalls dedicated to produce, sweets, sandwiches and more.
Your best bet for gelato is this bar that's been serving up some of the city’s best for a century.

cheatSheet.dek: From Fellini's favorite filming spots to Woody Allen's preferred piazza.

items.dek: Vatican City's pièce de résistance (and one of the location's for *The Godfather III*).
This ornate, monumentally sized fountain was one of the backdrops for Fellini's *La Dolce Vita*.
One of Rome's most famous landmarks, and one of the locations of the classic film *Roman Holiday*.
A Roman icon, and filming spot for *Eat, Pray, Love*, and *The Talented Mr. Ripley*, among others.
Fellini transformed these ancient baths into a nightclub—called Caracalla’s—in *La Dolce Vita*.
Woody Allen's chose this grand piazza as one of the locations in his 2012 film, *To Rome with Love*.

eat.hed: Best Restaurants in Testaccio, Rome's Original Foodie Neighborhood
eat.dek: Here are the absolute must-visit foodie spots in Rome's Testaccio neighborhood, where Roman cuisine was born.
eat.seoTitle: Best Restaurants in Testaccio, Rome's Original Foodie Neighborhood
eat.seoDescription: Here are the absolute must-visit foodie spots in Rome's Testaccio neighborhood, where Roman cuisine was born.
eat.socialTitle: Best Restaurants in Testaccio, Rome's Original Foodie Neighborhood
eat.socialDescription: Here are the absolute must-visit foodie spots in Rome's Testaccio neighborhood, where Roman cuisine was born.

items.caption:
It’s happened to the best of us—indulging in what we think is authentic Italian cuisine only to find out that it’s simply a fancier, once-frozen version of it. That’s why we skipped the overrated tourist traps, hopped on an [Eating Italy Food Tour](http://www.eatingitalyfoodtours.com/), and headed straight to Testaccio, the original foodie neighborhood of Rome—birthplace of “cuisine romana” and dubbed by the locals as the “Heart of Rome.” Here are the absolute must-visit spots in the city, featuring the best and most authentic food in all of Rome. 

*Pictured: Pizza from Volpetti Più.*

__THE FOOD:__ Pizza  
__THE SPOT:__ [Volpetti Più](http://www.volpetti.com/804/Volpetti-Piu)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Alessandro Volta 8

This cafeteria-style *tavola calda* offers some of the best *pizza al taglio* (pizza by the slice) in the city. The classic pizza margherita is their specialty, and they were rated third best of the some 1,500 pizza restaurants in Rome, according to our Eating Italy guide.

__THE FOOD:__ Meats and cheese  
__THE SPOT:__ [Volpetti](http://www.volpetti.com/home)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Marmorata 47

Find the finest selection of meats, cheeses, and wine at Volpetti, the deli owned by the same family that operates Volpetti Più. When you enter the store, you’ll be faced with tons of prosciutto (some aged for more than 40 years), truffled pecorino, and some of the best salami (infused with *barolo* wine) in the city.
Tip: Don’t forget to ask for samples.

__THE FOOD:__ Fresh produce and light bites  
__THE SPOT:__ Testaccio Market  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Beniamino Franklin

The Testaccio open-air market has been serving fresh, in-season produce to residents of this working-class neighborhood for generations. Here, you can touch, feel, and taste some of the freshest produce in the city.

__THE FOOD:__ Cannoli  
__THE SPOT:__ [Dess’Art](http://www.dessart.it/DessArt/Dessart.html)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Inside the Testaccio Market 

Locals will tell you the following about authentic cannoli: Only buy them from a Sicilian, and never purchase them pre-filled. Cannoli should be filled right after you order, on the spot. These cinnamon-seasoned cannoli were filled with ricotta cream and dipped in crushed pistachios.

__THE FOOD:__ Pasta  
__THE SPOT:__ [Flavio al Velavevodetto](https://www.facebook.com/pages/Flavio-Al-Velavevodetto-Quartiere-Testaccio-Roma/239639276118423)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via di Monte Testaccio 97

Flavio al Velavevodetto is an award-winning restaurant built into the side of Monte Testaccio, an old dump site turned into grass-covered hill. Years ago, the Romans dug into it and created caves to house their wine. Over time, local families turned these old wine cellars into restaurants. During our food tour, we sampled three different signature Italian pastas:

1. *Amatriciana*: A traditional pasta dish with sauce made from *guanciale* (cured pork cheek), pecorino cheese, and tomato.
2. Carbonara: This hearty pasta dish is made with egg yolk, pecorino cheese, guanciale (cured pork cheek), and black pepper—never cream.
3. *Cacio e Pepe*: As the name suggests, this authentic minimalist pasta is simple and made with Pecorino Romano cheese (*cacio*) and fresh black pepper (*pepe*).

__THE FOOD:__ Gelato  
__THE SPOT:__ [Giolitti](http://www.giolitti.it/en)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Amerigo Vespucci 35

Don’t be fooled by the hundreds of fancy gelato shops across Rome—our guide let us know that 90% of them put stabilizers and food dye in their flavors. Giolitti is a bustling neighborhood bar serving up some of the city’s best gelato since 1914. This historic establishment is loved by the locals, thanks to the homemade, authentic gelato.

fields.name: Jinna Yang
fields.shortBio: Jinna Yang is a lifestyle photographer and the Founder/Creative Director of [Grease and Glamour](http://greaseandglamour.com/), a visual destination serving up endless travel inspiration.
fields.bio: In April 2013, lifestyle photographer Jinna Yang quit her full-time fashion job to travel the world. She started sharing stories of her adventures on [Grease and Glamour](http://greaseandglamour.com/), helping inspire others to live life with purpose and follow their dreams. Founded in 2012, Grease and Glamour quickly became a platform for endless inspiration, showcasing some of the world's most beautiful destinations. Jinna’s work has been featured in Time Magazine, CNN Travel, Yahoo, BBC World Radio, and hundreds of other media outlets around the world.

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53daa82d6dec627b149f9803]||||||

When it comes to dining in Rome, there's one pasta dish to avoid, and one you shouldn't leave the city without trying.







**You should never order…**



 Fettuccine Alfredo. This is an American dish that has been imported to Italy, not the other way round. If you see it on a menu, you’re likely to have fallen into a tourist trap which caters for their idea of ‘tourist taste’.





**You can't leave Rome without eating…**



 _Cacio e Pepe_. The traditional Roman pasta dish is found on almost every menu in the city. Often made with spaghetti, it is a simple recipe of cacio cheese (Roman pecorino) and black pepper. No frills, just good quality ingredients that make this a Roman mainstay.

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53da834b6dec627b149ef1b0]||||||

[Panella](http://www.panellaroma.com), on Via Merulana, is often referred to as Rome’s best bakery. Whether or not that's true—anything labeled "Rome's best" is often highly contentious—it does boast divine chocolate croissants, pistachio-filled pastries, and truly excellent coffee.



But the real draw at Panella? This charming spot is always filled with energy; there's a thrill and freneticism in the air. It's perpetually packed with locals, meaning that it's consistently a battlefield ordering breakfast (particularly "to go"—a concept that is difficult for Italians to understand).







Be warned: The baristas, as skilful as they are at churning out amazing coffees from that stunning espresso machine, are not exactly the friendliest people on earth. Just for fun, I tried to capture how unpleasant they can be—but of course, today was the day she smiled! Oh, temperamental Italy. _Via Merulana 54; +39 06 487 2651_





**More on Rome:**



[Shop Like a Real Roman at MAS](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/magazzino-allo-statuto-mas-department-store-rome-italy)



[At This Roman Pastry Shop, the Packaging's As Delicious As the Pastry](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/il-giglio-pasticceria-rome-italy)



[The Best Spot to Score a Bike in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/bike-shop-vacation-travel-grappa-trastevere-rome-italy)

related.hed: A Sweet Tooth's Guide to Rome
related.dek: The Colosseum and *cacio e pepe* are great, but we know the real reason you're in Rome is for the tiramisu. And the gelato. And the cannoli. We put together a list of delicious desserts and classic treats to try while visiting the Eternal City.
related.seoDescription: We know the real reason you're in Rome is for the tiramisu. And the gelato. And the cannoli. Here's where to find the best of it.
related.socialDescription: We know the real reason you're in Rome is for the tiramisu. And the gelato. And the cannoli. Here's where to find the best of it.

items.title: For tiramisu: Bar Pompi
items.caption: Bar Pompi calls itself, quite seriously, *il Regno del Tiramisu* (the kingdom of tiramisu), which is a pretty lofty claim in Rome. But the 55-year-old pasticceria lives up to its tagline with spectacular tiramisu that many locals vow is truly the city's best. It's textbook perfect: beautiful layers of espresso-soaked savoiardi and creamy mascarpone, not too sweet or bitter, and surprisingly light but flavorful. Pompi offers several varieties‚ including strawberry, pistachio, banana and dark chocolate, and Nutella, but nothing beats the classic, finished off with cocoa and slivers of chocolate *(Via Albalonga 7; +39 06 700 0418; [www.barpompi.it](www.barpompi.it))*

items.title: For cannoli: Ciuri Ciuri
items.caption: This Sicilian gelateria and pasticceria slings everything from granita to cassata, but what you're here for are the cannoli. Each cannolo is made the only way it should be, piped with fresh ricotta just before it's served and not a moment before. Unlike many other cannoli, Ciuri Ciuri's version is light and crisp on the outside with an impossibly thin pastry shell and airy, just-sweet-enough ricotta. If that still sounds too decadent (is there such a thing?), they also offer cannolini, smaller versions you can devour in two bites. Ciuri Ciuri now has four Rome locations, but the original location in Monti remains the best and most popular. *(Via Leonina 18/19; +39 06 4544 4548; [www.ciuri-ciuri.it](www.ciuri-ciuri.it))*

items.title: For cornetti: Cafe Barberini
items.caption: Frankly, everything at this coffee bar and pasticceria‚ opened in 1934‚ is great. The miniature cups of tiramisu, Nutella-filled donuts, and delicate chantilly cream tarts topped with fruit are all worth sampling. But the cornetti? They're works of art. Made fresh every morning, Barberini's cornetti are so flaky and buttery they cling to your fingers. The plain cornetti are excellent paired with your morning cappuccino, but for a richer, dessert-like snack, get the cornetto con crema, filled with custard cream. *(Via Marmorata 41; +39 06 575 0869)*

items.title: For millefoglie: Pasticceria Cavaletti
items.caption: There might be versions of this cream-layered puff pastry dessert all across the world, but the Italians are gifted at making decadent pastries that are simultaneously (and dangerously) light and delicate. Here at Cavaletti, they've been making *millefoglie* cakes for over five decades, served in small, individual rounds that you can demolish yourself and huge squares that can serve an entire wedding party. Despite being filled with cream, buttery pastry, and almonds, their millefoglie still somehow feels ethereally light and fresh. Cavaletti also serves other great cakes— the Black Forest and Mont Blanc are standouts, but if you want to sink your teeth into their famous millefoglie, get there before noon. *(Via Nemorense 179; +39 06 8632 4814; [www.pasticceriacavalletti.it](www.pasticceriacavalletti.it))*

items.title: For gelato: Gelateria I Caruso
items.caption: We already told you about [Gelateria I Caruso](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-14/italys-best-gelato/2)  (and the equally great Come il Latte and Gelateria del Teatro) but a sweet tooth's guide to Rome would be incomplete without its presence. The gelato is made on-site while you watch through a glass window, and they'll top your scoop with fresh whipped cream, either plain or flavored with *zabaglione* (a sweet marsala wine). The seasonal citrus flavors steal the show in the summertime; any other time of year, the fiordipanna and pistachio flavors rule. *(Via Collina, 13-1, Rome; +39 06 4201 6420)*

items.title: For biscotti: Biscottificio Innocenti
items.caption: It's physically impossible to walk by this bakery without stopping to gawk at the trays upon trays of cookies (for which biscotti is the sweeping term in Italian) in the window. If the sight of it won't get you, the sweet, heady aroma will, and before you know it, you're inside the tiny shop with a white paper bag filled with warm biscotti plucked right from the oven. All of the homemade biscotti are fantastic; they have, after all, been making biscotti since 1920, but the nutty, crispy, chewy brutti ma buoni ("ugly but good") are especially popular. *(Via della Luce 21; +39 06 580 3926)*

items.title: For maritozzi con la panna: Regoli Pasticceria
items.caption: If you've never had a *maritozzo*, the classic Roman breakfast pastry, then this is your chance. Classically, maritozzi are sweet dough buns, sometimes made with raisins, pine nuts and candied peel, eaten plain. While they're delicious in their own right, because this is Italy, another (arguably better) version of maritozzi goes like this: the fresh bun is taken from the oven, split in half, spread like a book and then topped with a layer of cream so thick you can barely see the bread beneath. This is the version you will find at the renowned Regoli Pasticceria‚ equal parts bread and cream. Should you eat it daily? Definitely not. But don't leave Rome without trying it at least once. *(Via dello Statuto 60; +39 06 487 2812; [www.pasticceriaregoli.com](www.pasticceriaregoli.com))*

fields.shortBio: Krisanne Fordham is a contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler*

Krisanne grew up in Sydney, Australia and splits her time between New York and Italy.

related.hed: How to Shop Rome Like Zoolander 2's Costume Designer
related.dek: Hollywood costume designer Leesa Evans has worked on movies like Amy Schumer's *Trainwreck*and the upcoming *Zoolander 2*. But her favorite place to shop for her characters is the Eternal City.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/55afcda40121edec2570704e]||||||





Cinema has long celebrated the swank-meets-sophisticated Italian style; think the iconic circle skirt Audrey Hepburn wore scootering around on a Vespa in *Roman Holiday*and the tailored suit Marcello Mastroianni so elegantly inhabited in *La Dolce Vita.*Now *Zoolander 2,*filming in Rome this summer and starring Ben Stiller, Owen Wilson, and Penelope Cruz, continues that tradition of fashionable films. The film’s plot is under wraps, but we know that the original *Zoolander,*about a male model-turned-assassin known for his signature Blue Steel pose, was absurdist fun. Evans was able to share her favorite places to shop for the A-List cast (and herself!) when we caught up with her at Rome’s legendary Cinecittà Studios. 

__[Gente](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/gente)__

"The Romans have a level of formality I think is wonderful. Even in the high heat of summer, everyone still maintains an elegant uniform. And there’s a mode to shopping when you’re Roman and it’s patronizing smaller boutiques like Gente, which has an incredible selection from Valentino to Isabel Marant."


[#image: /photos/55afcda20121edec25707030]|||Gente|||



__[Leam](http://www.leam.com/en)__ 

"A different take on the high-end brands; one that’s a more curated collection from a large variety of designers. And something I found that was fun—their outlet store with all the clothes from previous seasons is right upstairs. I’m always looking for a bit of a deal."

__[Laura Urbinati](http://lauraurbinati.com/)__

"I love all their clothes but I’m obsessed with the swimwear. The fit is fantastic, the fabrics are beautiful, and the cut is hip and modern. I probably have a dozen suits. I stocked up because I’m afraid I’ll never get them again."

__[Monocle](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/monocle)__

"Chic, outrageous, and classic eyewear all in one place. It’s so sunny in Rome, a great pair of sunglasses is key for practical reasons and they also can make an outfit. We bought quite a few pieces from here for *Zoolander 2.*"


[#image: /photos/55afdf650121edec257072ad]|||Monocle|||






__Forme Di Pompeo Polito & C. Sas__

"If you can get away from touristy shopping areas, you can really come across some authentic Roman gems. This unique store specializes in midcentury jewelry."


__[Luna e L’altra](http://www.laltraluna.org/)__

I haven’t seen any other little store quite like this in all of Rome. They only carry Asian designers and it’s nice to find things that are unexpected. Plus, we need every kind of fashion on this film.”

[Scout](scout.it)

"If you need a break from formality, this is the place to get casual basics and cool sneakers with a street, skater flair. They make their own T-shirts out of the softest cotton that fit really well."


__[Lesley](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/lesley)__ 

“Take a peek into this high-end vintage resale store that carries items that are gently worn and sometimes not worn at all. I got a gorgeous red Bakelite, ’80s Chanel necklace that I used in a fashion show scene. They also have pieces like that Céline bag you’ve been coveting for a quarter of the original price.”


[#image: /photos/55afcda47772ff921f962a2f]|||Lesley|||





__[WP](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/wp)__

"They’ve got the perfect canvas boots, great hats and three-piece cotton suits. Basically, the kind of clothes you would want if you were going on a chic adventure—rugged yet fashionable. It seems like an oxymoron but the style really works."


[#image: /photos/55afcda87772ff921f962a4d]|||WP|||



__[Blue Marlin](bluemarlincompany.it)__


"Everything has this patina of cool. The store’s website calls the look ‘rusty.’ After all the shopping I’ve done here, there are just a few stores that really have something to offer that’s a little bit different."

__And for sustenance after a long day pounding the cobblestone streets, Evans recommends…__

[Dom Hotel](domhotelroma.com): “It’s fun to have drinks at their sweet rooftop bar right by Campo di Fiori."


[#image: /photos/55afcda27772ff921f962a11]|||Dom Hotel|||





[Etabli](etabli.it): “The perfect, charming place to grab a little appetizer."

[Pierluigi](pierluigi.it): "When you want to have a delicious dinner after a day of shopping."

[CamBio Vita](cibodistrada.it/locali/cambio-vita): “My favorite gelato place!"

She also shares one final shopping tip, in case you have any money left: “You can find vintage Fendi, Valentino, Versace—all sorts of amazing pieces—if you have the time to look on these three streets: Montivia dei Governo Vecchio and Via dei Banchi Vecchi in the Campo di Fiori area and Via del Boschetto in Monti.”

related.hed: Beyond the Colosseum: Roman Amphitheaters Outside of Rome
related.dek: You’ve crossed the Colosseum off your list, so now what?  The Roman Empire at its peak stretched around the Mediterranean and up into Europe, building thriving cities all the way. These 10 destinations boast some of the best preserved Roman amphitheatres outside Rome.

items.title: Pula, Croatia
items.caption: Pula, on the Istria Peninsula, is nearer to Venice or Zagreb than Dubrovnik. Its coastal location and red-roofed city centre draws comparison to that famous tourist city, however, with its scenic port and focus on the sea. Pula was once a major maritime stronghold for the Roman Empire with a population of over 30,000, hence the construction of the Pula Arena, between 27 BC - 68 AD, for the entertainment of the masses. It is one of the few Roman amphitheatres still mostly intact, with preserved tiers and subterranean galleries. These days the Arena is famous for hosting the Pula Film Festival, as well as many smaller public performances.

items.title: Aspendos, Turkey
items.caption: This ancient Greco-Roman city is only an hour’s drive from Antalya, and a popular day-trip for travelers beginning (or ending) a stay on the Turkish coast. Built in 155 AD and decorated for god of wine and theater, Dionysus, the city’s theatre once welcomed 7,000 guests to performances less bloody than its amphitheatre cousins around the Roman Empire. The focus here was on the finer arts, a practice continued today as the theatre plays host to the annual Aspendos Opera and Ballet Festival.

items.title: El-Jem, Tunisia
items.caption: Travelers feel as though they’re driving straight into the desert en route to the amphitheatre at El-Jem, but soon the massive structure appears on the horizon and dwarfs the town built around it. At its historic peak after opening around 238 AD, the amphitheatre could welcome 30,000 spectators to a single event. It is extraordinarily well-preserved, and walking through the dark underground passages it’s easy to picture the gladiators and wild animals which once traversed them. The month-long International Festival of Symphonic Music again fills the stands, as do smaller local performances.

items.title: Leptis Magna, Libya
items.caption: The classical ruins within Libya are legendary, as much for their extraordinary scale, preservation, and variety as for the difficulty of reaching them. The entire site of Leptis Magna is nearest the town of Khoms, nearly two hours’ drive from Tripoli, but is perhaps the least touristed of all sites on this list owing to Libya’s mercurial foreign relations, closed borders, and travel warnings and bans from other countries. That said, those who do visit set foot in a seemingly untouched amphitheatre from 56 AD, as well as sprawling baths and temples complexes.

items.title: Arles, France
items.caption: Although this theatre, “Les Arenes,” could only hold 20,000 guests compared to the 80,000 capacity of Rome’s Colosseum, its presence confirmed Arles’ importance in the Roman Empire as a major stop on the trade route between Italy and Spain. Ancient entertainment brought chariot races and bloodsports to Les Arenes, and the tradition continues on a smaller, safer level with regular bull fighting performances.
items.credit: LOOK Die Bildagentur der Fotografen GmbH / Alamy

items.title: Nîmes, France
items.caption: Located in southern France, Nîmes has a friendly rivalry with nearby Arles for the title of the “Rome of France.” Both cities boast a variety of Roman ruins, and both have, at their center, an impressively preserved amphitheatre. Nîmes’ was built in 70 AD and also recently transformed into a bull ring, but only Nîmes can say that it has hosted not one, not two, but three Depeche Mode concerts.

items.title: Pompeii, Italy
items.caption: With the shape of Mount Vesuvius on the horizon, the sad history of Pompeii’s amphitheatre is very much in the visitors’ mind. Built in 80 BC (before Rome’s Colosseum!) and buried by the horrendously destructive volcanic eruption in 79 AD, the amphitheatre didn’t see sunlight again until excavations began in earnest in the late 1700’s. Today the site welcomes modern performances, most famously Pink Floyd’s 1972 concert and documentary, “Live at Pompeii.”

items.title: Verona, Italy
items.caption: Fair Verona, where we lay our scene. Before Shakespeare made the city famous in ‘Romeo and Juliet’ and other works, it was a Roman military stronghold thanks to its convenient location at the intersection of major transportation routes. The Arena, built in 30 AD, is the third largest in the world (after Rome and Capua, near Naples) and the most active in terms of modern performances. Tickets to sit on tiers of the original Roman stone steps are cheaper than those to sit in the newer, padded chairs on the arena’s floor.

items.title: Lecce, Italy
items.caption: Walk through Lecce and inevitably you’ll find your route obstructed by a huge hole in the ground. Smack in the city centre is an ancient Roman amphitheater only discovered in 1901. By the 1930s, archaeological works had dug down to uncover and preserve enough of the 15,000-seat stadium to again welcome visitors for performances.

items.title: Siracusa, Sicily, Italy
items.caption: Travelers seeking sun at the beginning or end of summer can head south, to Sicily,  for a jumpstart on the season. While Taormina is a favorite for sunbathing, the town of Siracusa south of Mount Etna is the destination for tourists eager to spend at least some of the day exploring Roman ruins in the Neapolis Archaeological Park. The star may be the Greek Theatre, dating back to the 5th century AD, but visitors should be sure to stop in at the 1st century AD amphitheater, once home to bloody gladiator battles, and now host to much milder summer music performances.

fields.shortBio: Cynthia Drescher is a transportation enthusiast and contributing digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler*
fields.bio: Cynthia first moved to New York City with the idea of traveling anywhere and everywhere from JFK Airport. She's flown on aircraft fresh from the factory, scuba dived with sharks and shipwrecks, traveled to seven continents, and been first to check in at some of the world's newest hotels. She was managing editor of Jaunted.com for six years and her work has also appeared on HotelChatter.com, Jetsetter.com, Onboard.com, and Racked.com.

related.hed: Eternally Hers: Silvia Venturini Fendi's Rome
related.dek: For Silvia Venturini Fendi, whose family has helped to restore one of the world’s most historically rich yet surprisingly modern cities, finding beauty in the old and the new is second nature. We sat down with the quiet genius for her take on the place that shaped her enviable taste.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/55ce440837284fb1079ca028]|||
Silvia Venturini Fendi on the veranda at Palazzo della Civiltà Italiana, the new Fendi global headquarters, in Rome’s EUR district.
|||





"When my mother bought this hotel in 2004, she deliberately left things a bit decadent,” says Silvia Venturini Fendi, sitting on the edge of a 19th-century gilded chair, coffee in hand. She’s speaking of Villa Laetitia, the Art Nouveau hotel on the Tiber River where we’ve met today. “There’s nothing worse than hyper-restoration. We wanted a little patina. In Rome, this always seems to be the aim: to bring new life to old things.”

It’s a philosophy as Roman as Fendi herself, a designer responsible for the of-the-moment Peekaboo clutch (a riff on a bag she introduced in 2008), who still has her shirts and bespoke capes made at the Roman institution De Ritis. Today, she’s not wearing anything from the storied ecclesiastical tailor but rather an inky-black Fendi jacket and stovepipe pants, brown-black leather brogues, and gem-studded rings designed by her daughter Delfina Delettrez. Most noticeably, her signature burnished-blond bob—the one she’s worn since her 20s, when she teetered on vertiginous heels through social scenes on both sides of the Atlantic, making regular appearances at Studio 54 in between hosting the brand’s trunk shows—has been replaced by an almost boyish cap of sable-brown hair.

Hotel guests walk through the *salotto,*admiring the color-block canvases contrasting with the ornately corniced walls (though none appear to recognize the fashion scion herself; perhaps it’s the new hair). It’s a dichotomy she loves and sees everywhere in her city. “Take the Centrale Montemartini,” in the industrial zone of Ostiense, she says, her hands subconsciously pressing together in a quintessentially Italian gesture that communicates the approval her modulated tone doesn’t. “It’s an old power plant that’s now a museum, and its beauty is that all the dials and machines have stayed exactly the same but they’ve placed incredible art in front of them. It creates an amazing contrast.” She shrugs and sits back, smiling. “This is Rome: the old and the new, always in tension, and you don’t know which you like better. The dialogue, though, is always interesting.”



[#image: /photos/55ce407f37284fb1079c9f20]|||
The restored ceiling at Villa Laetitia, the Fendi family’s Art Nouveau hotel in the Prati neighborhood.
￼
|||



Fendi, 54, comes from a long line of women not afraid of creating tension. In the 1950s, when many Italians still balked at the idea of women working outside the home, her grandmother Adele had parlayed the family furriers, founded in 1925, into a thriving accessories business with the help of her five daughters, Paola, Alda, Franca, Carla, and Anna. And it was Anna and her sisters who appointed a young German named Karl Lagerfeld as designer in 1965, when Silvia was still a little girl. Over a decade later, he launched the ready-to-wear line, sending the brand on its propulsive trajectory. “My mother, Anna, was always called the most creative of the five,” Fendi says. “She said it about herself, and everyone else said it too. This hotel is a perfect example. Design, fashion, interiors: It was all linked for her. And it’s complicated to succeed at all of them—you really have to have a vision.”

Growing up in one of Rome’s most illustrious families, Silvia moved between rarefied society and the prosaic atmosphere of the atelier, to which Anna brought her from the time she could toddle (she claims to have preferred the company of its artisans to that of her Barbie dolls). She joined the company in 1987 as creative director of the Fendissime line, but it wasn’t until 1997 that she had a real breakthrough when she introduced the first it bag, the Baguette—the same one stolen from *Sex and the City’s*Carrie Bradshaw on the street. 

Today, she is the only family member still employed by the brand (which was sold to LVMH in 2001). As creative director of accessories, she remains close to the handcraftsmanship that the Fendi ethos is based on—something she says she’s more inspired by these days than the seasonal ebb and flow of trends.


[#image: /photos/55ce408437284fb1079c9f59]|||
A set piece at the Fendi fall/winter 2015/16 show by Swiss artist Sophie Taeuber-Arp, who inspired the collection.
|||








It makes sense, then, that gritty but fast-gentrifying Ostiense—“very different from the Rome of people’s minds; very *popolare,*not monumental”—is one of Fendi’s favorite parts of town. “The important things have stayed the same here.” As much as Rome’s historic center, or Cinecittà (where family friend Federico Fellini once convinced the five sisters to show their collection), Ostiense is a backdrop to Fendi’s own history. Her daughter Delfina lives in Ostiense now; on Sundays she’ll eat at Al Biondo Tevere, a 101-year-old trattoria that all three Fendi generations have patronized (as did director Pier Paolo Pasolini, immortalized in photos along its walls). “Because she’s been going since she was a baby, they’ll let her sneak into the kitchen and get takeout.” Wilting ferns and plastic chairs dot the courtyard; the interiors, in old-school Italian fashion, have lighting that is entirely too bright. “But I love the simplicity of it,” Fendi says. “Even the chairs—because they’ve been there forever. Those plastic chairs are charming because they’re authentic.”

> I understood from when I was just a girl that things have history.

Fendi takes pleasure in finding beauty in parts of her city where others might not so readily see it. The Fascist-era Palazzo della Civiltà Italiana, for instance, on the outskirts of Rome—to which Fendi moved its headquarters in February from an ultra-central 18th-century palazzo—“must be considered from the architectural point of view,” she says, her fingers flicking outward in another ur-Italian gesture of dismissal toward anyone unsophisticated enough not to do this. “Of course, everyone is still a bit nervous to talk about this era, but the Palazzo’s spaces are just amazing. And also a bit metaphysical—very De Chirico. It was actually [chairman and CEO of Fendi] Pietro Beccari’s idea to make the move. At first I thought, ‘Is he a bit crazy?’ But the light and energy are fantastic. It’s the highest building in Rome—only six stories but on a hill, so we have extraordinary views. And the Carrara marble it’s made from is to die for. It is rationalist, and pure, and beautiful.”



[#image: /photos/55ce408437284fb1079c9f5c]|||
The Piscina dei Mosaici—in 1985, Fendi became the first fashion house to stage a show at the stadium.
|||







To spend time with Fendi is to understand that authenticity holds a lot of sway with her. It informed the 2011 publication of *The Whispered Directory of Craftsmanship,*her A-to-Z guide to Italian artisans producing everything from *mezzelune biscotti*to bicycles to *passementerie.*“[Taste] is so universal today. You can buy Modica chocolate in Tokyo. There’s all this access, but people want to know about provenance, about the where and how.” Flipping through a copy, Fendi pauses on the page for Lavori Artigianali Femminili, the exquisite children’s clothing boutique just off the Piazza di Spagna, her face softening into a smile. “I was dressed here from the day I was born; so was Delfina, and now [my granddaughter] Emma. Some of the ladies who fitted me as a child are still there.”

Such places—of which her city is full—“can help you have a cultural sense of beauty, can help in constructing your style,” she says. “I understood from when I was just a girl that things have history and tradition. Objects are not just objects.” And cities? “When you’re raised here, appreciating beauty is in your blood. Then again, we often don’t pay attention; for us, it’s normal to walk on ancient stones.”

She continues to idly flip through one of *The Whispered*’s volumes, then pauses at a dog-eared page, her focus as bright and direct as a bird’s. “We really need to do another one of these soon.”


----------

fields.name: Maria Shollenbarger
fields.shortBio: London-based contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Born and raised in Los Angeles and educated in New England and Italy, Maria Shollenbarger now calls East London home. She worked at *InStyle*and *Travel + Leisure,* among others, before joining *Condé Nast Traveler* in October 2013. She is the Travel Editor for *How To Spend It,* the luxury supplement to the Financial Times.

featuredEats.name: Roscioli
featuredEats.description: Foodies flock to this specialty food and wine shop, which also has a restaurant where the bottle-lined walls and cheese-and-salumi display case make a fitting backdrop for some of the best and most elevated versions of traditional Roman starters, pastas, and meat-centric cuisine you'll find in the Eternal City.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Don't miss the burrata topped with caviar at this food and wine shop-cum-restaurant.

featuredEats.name: Armando al Pantheon
featuredEats.description: Despite being in the heart of the tourist crush, this old-school, wood-paneled spot remains beloved by locals for the most typical of Roman pasta and meat dishes, from carbonara (a pasta sauce of egg and bacon-like guanciale) to coda alla vaccinara (stewed oxtail). There are also plenty of vegetarian options, a surprise in Rome.
featuredEats.shortDescription: A local favorite for classics like carbonara and cacio e pepe near the Pantheon.

featuredEats.name: Barnum Café
featuredEats.description: It may not offer the circus-like atmosphere promised by its name—you're more likely to find patrons plugging away at laptops than acrobats dangling from trapezes—but this high-ceilinged, playfully decorated spot near Campo de'Fiori offers some of the best classic and creative cocktails in town.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Expertly crafted cocktails make this Campo de'Fiori spot popular with young creative types.

fields.caption:
**


 BARNUM CAFÉ**





**What:** Until recently, discerning drinkers near the Campo de’ Fiori were better off sticking to wine. But then ace bartenders stepped in at Barnum, which serves coffee by day and excellent cocktails after 6 p.m.





**The look:** Whitewashed brick walls and wood beams in the front room; the back is even cozier with dim lighting, well-worn sofas, and a carpenter’s table.





**Who goes:** Young Romans weary of the neighborhood’s watery cocktail norm. >>

featuredEats.name: Pierluigi
featuredEats.description: A favorite of the old-school Roman *borghesia*, Pierluigi serves excellent fish, and standard Roman *primi*(pasta cacio e pepe, amatriciana, and carbonara) in a white-tablecloth way that’s elegant rather than too formal or fussy. For dessert, don’t miss the house-made sorbet platter, served in hollowed out frozen fruits and nutshells.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Open since the '30s, this white-tablecloth stalwart serves some of the city’s best fish.

miniGuides.dek: Once you set foot in Rome's centro storico and get a taste of the near-endless beauty there, it’ll feel like a crime that you don’t have more time. The best way to get a full fix in a short period? Walk. Just weave your way along the narrow, crooked streets of Rome’s most scenic areas: the medieval and Renaissance rioni of Ponte, Parione, and Regola.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548b4c09b6e03e8c2d0cc0aa]|||
Mingle with locals while shopping along Via del Governo Vecchio.|||



##PLAY HERE

The Via del Governo Vecchio is one the city’s quirkiest and most original shopping streets, lined with vintage clothiers, haberdasheries, and purveyors of fancy foodstuffs. But make sure to look up, too: the *palazzo* that line it, washed in sorbet tones of pink, yellow, and apricot, are some of Rome’s most patrician, colliding in happy accidents of prettiness. Start at the Piazza Pasquino and make your way towards the Tiber: Check out the jewelry at __[Delfina Delettrez](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/delfina-delettrez)__ and __[Nicotra di San Giacomo](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/nicotra-di-san-giacomo)__, the chic womenswear at __[Josephine de Huertas](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/josephine-de-huertas)__, and heritage menswear at __[Wools](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/rome/wools)__.


[#image: /photos/548b4c09860c74c1162c8f6d]|||
Find a sense of calm in the middle of bustling Rome at Chiostro del Bramante. 
|||


##REST HERE

About two blocks north of the Via del Governo Vecchio, the __[Chiostro del Bramante](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/chiostro-del-bramante)__ is a bastion of tranquility—a remarkable fact, given that the madness of the Piazza Navona is just a few hundred feet distant. It’s a small, perfectly formed gem of high Renaissance architecture, with a courtyard, a small gallery space, and, upstairs, a sleek little café with tables around the pergola—and the ideal place to catch your breath with a pitch-perfect *café corretto* and revel in that rarest of Roman commodities: quiet. 

##EAT HERE

Cross the Viale Vittorio Emanuele to the *rione* of Regola. Walk up the Via de’ Monserrato to the tiny, sun-filled Piazza de’ Ricci, and grab an alfresco table at __[Pierluigi](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/rome/pierluigi)__. A stalwart for the old-school Roman *borghesia,* it serves excellent fish, and standard Roman *primi* (pasta cacio e pepe, amatriciana, and carbonara) in a white-tablecloth way that’s elegant rather than too formal or fussy. For dessert, don’t miss the house-made sorbet platter, served in hollowed out frozen fruits and nutshells.
miniGuides.seoDescription: Only have three hours in Rome? Spend that time wandering along the narrow, crooked streets of Rome’s most scenic areas: the medieval and Renaissance rioni of Ponte, Parione, and Regola.
