miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548b527e860c74c1162c8fc9]|||
Built in 13 BC, the Ara Pacis is a monument dedicated to peace.
|||





If you had to narrow Rome’s many fetching attributes down to one single selling point, it would have to be how effortlessly the ancient past and the electric present merge everywhere: in its cuisine, its culture, and its hospitality. Because the city is compact and dense, three days is actually an ideal stay. Work your way from the once-hardscrabble, now thoroughly gentrified streets of Trastevere across the Tiber and through the gorgeous jumble of the Campo Marzio, then venture out to a less-explored suburb – on foot, or astride a vintage Vespa with a guide. 


[#image: /photos/548b527fb6e03e8c2d0cc18a]|||
The Galleria Doria Pamphilj is home to a wide and varied art collection, possibly the largest in Italy still under private ownership. 
|||





##Day 1

__STAY:__ __[Donna Camilla Savelli](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/vatican-city/hotel-donna-camilla-savelli)__  
We’re not sure it gets better than sleeping in a Borromini-designed former convent in Trastevere. Minimalists might want to check in elsewhere, but if early Baroque splendor – heavy walnut furniture, dark coffered ceilings, polished terracotta floors – is your thing, book one of its 78 rooms, some with views up to the Villa Aurelia. In the morning, you can enjoy your coffee in the hushed courtyard, planted with herbs and rosebushes.

__EAT__

Hidden among the antiques and furniture dealers on a tiny side street off the Via dei Coronari, __[Gelateria Del Teatro](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-03-13/rome-italy-hidden-secret-tourist-spots-churches-gardens-gelato)__ is of very modest dimensions for a place that packs such a delicious punch: the owner used to be a pastry chef, and favors pistachios and walnuts from Sicily, lemons from Amalfi, and creative deployment of unexpected ingredients (sage; thyme; wine grapes).

__PLAY__

The __[Galleria Doria Pamphilj](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/galleria-doria-pamphilj)__ is a near-overdose art high: packed densely with 17th-century Flemish, Italian, English and Spanish masters (Velazquez’s famous portrait of Innocent X  – yes, he was a Doria-Pamphilij – hangs here), it also gives you a window into how the palazzo’d half lives: the private apartments, in which the family still resides, are open to the public on certain days of the week. 

No other monument in Rome marries the ancient with the contemporary as aptly, and beautifully, as does the __[Ara Pacis](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/ara-pacis-museum)__. The altar to peace, built by Caesar Augustus in 13 BC, has since 2006 AD been encased – or showcased, really – in a masterpiece of steel, glass, and marble designed by Richard Meier. It hosts rotating photography and painting exhibitions as well. 

__EAT__

__[Armando al Pantheon](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/rome/armando-al-pantheon)__, a stone’s throw from the monument of the same name,  recently had a makeover, bringing its more than 50-year-old interiors up to speed with the 21st century. Their new sleekness might have rankled a few old-timers, but the Roman standards the Gargioli family turns out (think artichokes, chicory, oxtail and suckling pig, in various delectable permutations) still impress with their consistent excellence.

__DRINK__

Even in Rome, sometimes a late-night beer – especially if it’s a craft brew from Baladin founder and Eataly superstar Teo Musso – can hit the spot. At __[No.Au](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/rome/no-au)__, hidden away behind the Piazza Navona, they also specialize in potato chips: hand-cut and fried on site, salty and transportingly delicious. (There are great small-production wines by the glass, and a few other snacks on the menu, too. But those chips; we’re telling you. Heaven.)


[#image: /photos/548b5284b6e03e8c2d0cc1b5]|||
Although most people associate Rome with classical art, the modernist wonder of MAXXI is winning raves. 
|||


-----------------


## Day 2

__STAY__

It’s the unbeatable location that sold us on __[DOM](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/rome/dom)__. The dark, velvet-lined bar and narrow restaurant might not be to all tastes, but the rooms are sumptuous and light-filled – studies in opulent silks and linens, brass and stone – and the roof terrace affords quite a horizon: the rosy dome of Vatican, the Juniculum, and the myriad terraces of the *centro storico.*

__EAT__

Flush at the border of buzzy [Testaccio](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-02-11/rome-neighborhood-guide-the-new-scene) and up-and-coming Ostiense is __[Porto Fluviale](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/rome/porto-fluviale)__, a multi-venue tribute to *la gastronomia romana.*You can drink a good negroni in the bar, compare the virtues of Neopolitan (doughy crust) and Roman (thin crust) pizzas in the dual-oven pizzeria, or get versed in how Romans do nose-to-tail at the charcuterie counter.

Should your carnivore pangs still not be met, head for Monte [Testaccio](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-09-12/unexpected-places-to-visit-in-rome), and __[Flavio al Velavevodetto](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/rome/flavio-al-velavevodetto)__, which is literally built into the side of the famous ‘mountain’ (actually a hill of ancient Roman detritus). The rigatoni *alla gricia*– cacio cheese, guanciale, and tons of black pepper – is bar-setting; the *polpette*have achieved near-legendary status; and the *abbacchio*(roast lamb) with potatoes and broccoli is enormous - one portion feeds two.  

__PLAY__

Whether or not you’re a Zaha Hadid fan, __[MAXXI](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/maxxi)__ is the face of 21st century Rome (or at least one of them). The building’s an opinion divider, but the exhibitions earn universal praise: the work of William Kentridge, Francesco Vezzoli, Antonio Citterio, and dozens of others cycle through the exhibition spaces each year. The courtyard and outdoor café are a great place for little ones to run off excess energy or bask in the sun.

__DRINK__

By day, __[Barnum Café](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/rome/barnum-cafe)__, around the corner from the Palazzo Farnese, is a coffee bar; after dark, however, it morphs into one of the only places in this city to serve truly good cocktails: these bartenders know their London drys, their single malts, and just about everything else—but the vibe is 100% Roman. 

If wine is your thing, go old-school: two of the most atmospheric *enoteche*in Rome are a five-minute walk from each other. __[Il Goccetto](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/rome/enoteca-il-goccetto)__ and __[Angolo Divino](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/rome/angolo-divino)__ both have rustic interiors, walls lined with top bottles, both big-name and obscure, and glass counters filled with small nibbles  – *tramezzini,* nice breads, olives and, at Il Goccetto, a killer cheese plate.


[#image: /photos/548b5451860c74c1162c8fe7]|||
The Palazzo Colonna is home to one of the most storied, aristocratic families in Italy—and their art collection.
|||





## Day 3

__STAY__

The __[The First Luxury Art Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/vatican-city/first-hotel)__ may jar a bit on first look – the entrance features some loud artwork and a piece or two of eyebrow-raising furniture – but the artfully-conceived rooms, their tone neutral and calming in contrast to the shouty public spaces, and great-value prices (for such a central location and such genial service) make up for it, as does the roof bar, which morphs into one of the city’s top sushi restaurants in summertime.

__EAT__

The great contention among Rome aficonadoes: where’s the best coffee? Purists favor __[Caffe Sant’Eutachio](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/rome/sant-eustachio-il-caff)__, which is all-coffee-all-the-time: drink your faultless macchiato, buy your beans, read about the roasting, even – and admire the façade of the church of the same name while you sip.

Those of a more social bent, though, can be found at __[Caffe della Pace](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/rome/caff-della-pace)__, deep in the *rione*of Parione, which by day is a conventional café, but by night doubles as a bar, lounge, and ground zero for flaneurs of all stripes. (The coffee, for the record, is excellent.) caffedellapace.it

__PLAY__

Until recently, you had to be a VIP to access the private galleries of the __[Palazzo Colonna](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/palazzo-colonna)__, one of the grandest private homes in the city (Colonnas have lived here for 450 years; they’ve been Roman aristocracy for 800). It’s now open to the public, and stuffed with an artistic patrimony that anywhere else would earn it its own museum wing: Caracci, Bronzino, Tintoretto, and Veronese are just a few of the all-stars whose work graces the ornate spaces. Have your hotel concierge book ahead for a private tour on Saturday. 

You know you want to tool around the Eternal City on a vintage Vespa like Gregory Peck did in *Roman Holiday*(you know your teenager does). The folks at __[Scooteroma Tours](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/rome/scooteroma-tours)__ know too. You can simply explore the *centro storico*with a guide, or you can theme a four-hour excursion: taste pastries in Trastevere or cheese in the ghetto, for instance, or follow the trail of the film *La Grande Bellezza.*They also do Fiat 500, “ape” (a three-wheeled truck like a tuk-tuk) and bicycle tours. 

__DRINK__

Some clichés pack a legitimate punch: on a mild Thursday or Friday evening in spring or early summer, the __[Stravinskij Bar](http://cnt.conde.io/bars/rome/stravinskij-bar)__ at the __[Hotel de Russie](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/vatican-city/hotel-de-russie--rome)__ is one of them. Sure, the drinks are fine, but that’s not what you come for: you come for the lush, terraced garden and the social networking playing out among the Roman glitterati (level of difficulty: Olympic, though of course, these being Romans, it looks effortless).

__EAT__

Venture out to the slightly snoozy, northwest-of-central Pinciano district to have a long lunch at __[Marzapane](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/rome/marzapane)__: the tasting menus – one of meat, one of fish – draw the likes of former mayor Walter Veltroni, who’s a regular, as well as the city’s top food critics, who all rave about its elevated versions of *maialino*and *carbonara. *

play.dek: Legendary Italian director Federico Fellini infused The Eternal City with his very own brand of fantastical fun. Here are some of the spots that Fellini made famous in Rome.
play.hed: In Their Shoes: Federico Fellini’s Rome

items.caption: To the outside world, Italy’s capital city is a bastion of beauty and sophistication. And while legendary Italian director Federico Fellini likely wouldn’t argue that point, such a sentiment might also cause him to chuckle. Because he also saw The Eternal City’s surrealistic side, and chose to highlight that aspect in the many films he shot there, most notably _La Dolce Vita _and _Roma. _ Here, we look back at some of the 12-time Oscar nominee’s most inspired (and memorable) locations.

items.title: [Trevi Fountain](http://www.turismoroma.it/cosa-fare/2742?lang=en)
items.caption: One of Rome’s most famous attractions is also its most famous depiction of _La Dolce Vita—_the famed fountain in which Anita Ekberg and Marcello Mastroianni splashed around. The fountain’s connection to the actors is so iconic that when Mastroianni passed away in 1996, it was turned off and draped in black as a tribute to his legacy.

items.title: [Harry’s Bar](http://www.harrysbar.it/?lang=en)
items.caption: This longtime hotspot owes its international acclaim in part to Fellini himself, who featured the Via Veneto eatery in _La Dolce Vita. _But the bar was also a celebrity hangout before Fellini’s imprimatur—Ernest Hemingway and Truman Capote both quaffed there—and has remained so for the past half-century.

items.title: [Al Moro](http://www.ristorantealmororoma.com)
items.caption: Just a few steps from the Trevi Fountain, Al Moro is an old-school Roman trattoria serving traditional plates of salumi, cheese, freshly made pastas, and decadent desserts, with locally sourced ingredients. Grab one of the restaurant’s outdoor tables for a people-watching experience that can only be described as “Felliniesque.”

items.title: [Baths of Caracalla](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/04/what-to-skip-in-rome-tourism-alternatives)
items.caption: In true surrealist style, Fellini transformed the city’s ancient thermal baths into a nightclub—called Caracalla’s—in _La Dolce Vita, _where Ekberg’s entrancing dance moves garner more attention than the ancient mosaics that still exist today (even if it’s more frequently used as an outdoor music venue).

items.title: Parco degli Acquedotti
items.caption:
Fellini isn’t the only filmmaker who made cinematic use of this breathtaking public park, which is named for the many aqueducts that inhabit it. Its proximity to Cinecittà, the famed Italian studio where Martin Scorsese shot _Gangs of New York_, has made it fair game for many moviemakers. For Fellini, it made for the perfect opening location for _La Dolce Vita_, where a statue of Jesus Christ dangles precariously from a helicopter along the Aqua Claudia.













**More ways to follow in artists' footsteps:





 **[In Their Shoes: Walt Whitman's Brooklyn](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/05/walt-whitman-guide-to-brooklyn)




[In Their Shoes: Alfred Hitchcock’s San Francisco](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/06/in-their-shoes-alfred-hitchcock-s-san-francisco)




[In Their Shoes: The Round Table’s Los Angeles](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/06/los-angeles-attractions-to-celebrate-the-round-table-anniversary)

play.hed: Unexpected Places to Visit In Rome
play.dek: Want the real Rome experience? Put that guidebook away and get lost in these under-the-radar neighborhoods.
play.body:
[#image: /photos/5413099217e4b1f634ef0183]||||||





Most tourists visiting the Eternal City generally stick to the landmark-heavy heart of Centro Storico. Here, at the nucleus of Rome’s historic center, you’ll find the Pantheon, the Trevi Fountain, the Spanish Steps, Piazza Navona, and the bulk of the city’s major hotels. Many also venture southeast to the Colosseum, or cross the Tiber River to St. Peter’s Basilica, Castel Sant’Angelo, and Vatican City, but few visitors veer from the typical tour bus route. This is perfectly fine if landmarks are all you’re after. However, if you’re looking for a real Roman experience, you need to wander off the standard guidebook grid and explore the city’s hidden corners. 

Beyond the well-trodden tourist paths, Rome boasts many interesting, exciting neighborhoods, from the hip, bohemian streets of Monti, to Pigneto’s leafy pedestrian thoroughfares. We suggest making time in your itinerary to get lost in the following neighborhoods.

##PIGNETO

Located in Rome’s easternmost corner, Pigneto is a triangular grid that’s a strange mix of leafy semi-suburbia and artsy urbanism. Its blend of denizens are just as strange—immigrants, artists, musicians, elderly Italians, hipsters, and the odd yuppie family—who all do their own thing. It’s the kind of place where you can shop at the farmer’s market alongside Italian nonnas carrying fresh-cut flowers, then walk down the street and watch graffiti artists tag a dilapidated storefront, then catch a poetry reading at a groovy bookshop-cum-café. It’s mainstream (it’s definitely “come up” already) yet offbeat, and somehow, it all works effortlessly.

__WHY VISIT?__ Pigneto’s *isola pedonale* is a bustling, happy, pedestrian-only thoroughfare alive with pizzerias, cafés, gelaterias, beer shops and music venues—essentially, a cool place to kill time in. For a good (and really affordable) feed, go to Pigneto Quarantuno and order their *cacio e pepe* and a carafe of house wine.






##TRASTEVERE 

[#image: /photos/54130e9d17e4b1f634ef01cf]|||Piazza Santa Maria|||

Across the river from Rome’s ancient ruins, you’ll find the colorful, exhilarating noise of Trastevere. Historically, Trastevere was a working-class district on Rome’s undesirable outskirts; it’s now a trendy neighborhood that’s considered part of the Centro Storico. Trastevere is a gathering place for local artists, students (it’s home to two American universities), expats and tourists; consequently, it feels both foreign yet very deeply Roman. While its narrow, maze-like streets teem with new bars, clubs, boutiques and bookshops, the area is still classically Italian with its quintessential ochre-washed homes, lively piazzas, charming cafés, and beautiful old churches (don’t leave without visiting the Basilica di Santa Maria and admiring its exquisite Cavallini mosaics).

__WHY VISIT?__ Every Sunday, the fantastic Porta Portese flea market takes place on Via Portuense and the adjacent streets between Porta Portese (the city gate) and Via Ettore Rolli. You won’t find a flea market anywhere that’s this large, crazy or filled with fascinating items for sale: dirt cheap antiques, clothing, artwork, books, and everything else in between. Any other day of the week, Piazza Santa Maria is alive with street performers, music and general revelry—and is also flanked by many good, cheap restaurants.

##MONTI

You don’t actually have to venture far from the tourist traps to find Monti—the neighborhood’s hidden in plain sight, east of the Roman Forum and just north of the Colosseum. In ancient Roman times, Monti was considered a slum, though it’s hard to picture that today; with its eclectic boutiques, chic wine bars, organic markets, and indie galleries, the area is hip with a bohemian edge. At the same time, Monti has somehow retained a cozy, “small village” feel and still possesses fragments of old-world Italian charm with its Renaissance remnants and old-fashioned trattorias.

__WHY VISIT?__ Monti is smaller and arguably less popular than Trastavere—and that’s exactly why you should go. Here, you’ll get a real taste of community, particularly at the lively Piazza della Madonna dei Monti. Sit on the sunny, crowded steps of its fountain while enjoying the terrific gelato from nearby Fatamorgana, or dine al fresco at La Bottega del Caffè and watch as kids play and locals go about their business.

##TESTACCIO

Unlike Trastavere or Monti, Testaccio’s not quite hip—yet. It’s a slightly unusual neighborhood built around Monte Testaccio, an ancient, artificial hill made out of discarded amphorae and terracotta tile (now covered in grass). There are no famous historical landmarks in Testaccio; though some popular clubs and bars have clustered at the base of the hill, the area’s more of a working-class wonderland than a tourist attraction. But that’s exactly what makes it so exciting, particularly when it comes to food: Testaccio is where traditional *cucina romana* was born, and where it still lives. 

__WHY VISIT?__ Food fiends, take note: the culinary offerings in Testaccio are some of Rome’s best. From the gastronomic heaven that is Volpetti—a deli crammed with meats, cheese, and other gourmet goodies—to the sweets at *pasticerria* Barberini (or newcomer Sicilia e Duci), Testaccio rules the food scene. Don’t visit without dining at the beloved Flavio al Velavevodetto, built into the side of Monte Testaccio—the carbonara, fettuccine, and rabbit cacciatore are to die for.

items.caption:
[**Ponte della Musica**](http://www.archdaily.com/179789/ponte-della-musica-buro-happold/)




The Bridge of Music was just unveiled last summer. A 200-meter-long, steel and white pedestrian and bicycle bridge designed by Bruno Happold, it creates a new public space for outdoor concerts, gathering, or just hanging out above the Tiber.

[**Maxxi**](http://www.maxxi.beniculturali.it/)




Crossing the Ponte della Musica brings you to Maxxi, a contemporary-art museum designed by British starchitect Zaha Hadid. Set in the context of the 19th-century, working-class Flaminio neighborhood, the Maxxi's glass, steel, and concrete form makes a forward-looking statement.

[**Ara Pacis Museum**](http://www.richardmeier.com/current/PROJECTS/AraPacis.html)




Construction of the Maxxi took a long time—nearly as long as the much-delayed [Parco della Musica](http://www.auditorium.com)  (2001) by Renzo Piano across the road and much-disputed Ara Pacis (2006) just down the Tiber (pictured). The delay lent weight to the argument that Rome is unfriendly to new architecture. A tough place to build.

[**MACRO**](http://www.macro.roma.museum/)




This modern-art museum (opened in 2002) was designed by French architect Odile Decq. Occupying the site of a former Peroni brewery, it’s marked by bright red shapes and undulating walkways.

**[Tiburtina train and metro station](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roma_Tiburtina_railway_station)**







On the opposite side of town, there are two other contemporary architecture projects that have attracted much attention: One is the yet-to-be-built Nuvola (Cloud) by Massimiliano Fuksas, which will be Rome's new convention center. There’s a lot of speculation around the final design of this creation, but paper drawings show an amorphous, gravity-defying cloud that will hold a 1500-seat auditorium suspended inside an enormous rectangular glass building. The other is Paolo Desideri’s Tiburtina train and metro station (pictured). Inaugurated on November 28, is the architectural centerpiece in a larger urban plan that envisions Rome as a history-filled urban metropolis—constantly looking forward, but aware of its past.

pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d9846dec627b149dc473]|||Da Enzo|||

When I see innocent tourists in Rome fawning over frozen pizza and generic gelato, I just want to take them by their t-shirts, scrub their sticky, tiramisu-covered fingertips, and finally (basta!) feed them food that tastes like, well, Italy. Here are five, trusted Roman ristorantes that the tourist books don’t tell you about.










##### Da Enzo


Local Italians cherish [this place](http://www.daenzoal29.com/) (pictured above). They would protect it from all of us English-speakers if they could. Located in the most peaceful part of eastern Trastevere, this genuine Roman trattoria has a serious focus on quality of ingredients, with all their eggs, meat, wine and cheese being 100% organic. Here, the concept of “kilometer zero” is not a gimmick, but a religion—the olive oil comes from the verdant Viterbo area (north Lazio), all produce comes from nearby farms. The setting isn't fussy at all—clean and simple, with children's artwork hung on its sunshine yellow walls. But the food is out of this world. Da Enzo is especially known for its carciofi judia, cacio e pepe, stuffed zucchini blossoms, and perfectly-salted baccalà. My advice? Order anything with artichokes. _(Via dei Vascellari 29; +39 06 58 12 260)_










##### Osteria Bonelli


While Osteria Bonelli is not far from the chic Pignetto, the restaurant’s specific location in Torpignattara is on the side of seedy. And that nice-to-rough ratio—superb food on cheap paper tablecloths—is exactly what you’ll find inside this always-bustling osteria, where the dishes are truly exceptional and the waitresses, in their thick black eyeliner, know exactly what you want before you say a word (which is good because there are no menus). I lick my plate every time I eat there, inhaling the ricotta e spinaci ravioli and pasta alla gricia, guzzling the wonderful house red wine, before looking at the bill and crying out loud about how cheap it is. Of course, no one can understand me. The closest thing to English is a crooked, black and white framed photograph of Steve Jobs, with the quote, “Siate affamati! Siate folli!” Translation: “Stay Hungry. Stay Foolish.” _(Viale dell'Acquedotto Alessandrino, 172; +39 329 863 3077)_










##### Farinè


This National School of Pizza-trained husband and wife operation is no joke, with five strict selections of Roman-style pizza per night, with no substitutions, no exceptions, and no decisions – other than “beer or wine?” On the menu, you will find these options: Margarita, Mediterranean, Napoli, Marinara, Mozzarella & Anchovies and a seasonal Daily Special. Wife cooks, husband serves. The pizza is quickly sliced, and then unceremoniously delivered on a slab of paper (no plate), in sizes small, medium or large. Yes, Farinè is a peculiar, ultra-simple place, with a slightly hostile attitude, but none of that matters because the pizza is just so perfect. Why? The dough has a long, 72-hour rise, resulting in a strong, fluffy crust, and the ingredients are hyper-fresh bought daily from nearby markets. This locals-only pizzeria takes minimalism to another level (albeit unintentionally): There’s one table, no forks, and zero staff. Strange and splendido! _(Via degli Aurunci, 6/8; +39 06 445 1162)_










##### La Carbonara dal 1906


Hurry. Word is getting out about [La Carbonara](http://www.lacarbonara.it/) in Monti. With generous portions of traditional homemade pastas like (my favorite) Ravioli alle Noci, classic dishes like fritto vegatale, and bollito dressed with olive oil and lemon, not to mention all the impassioned Italian graffiti on the walls, the experience here is never dull. Especially if you order the spicy pasta zi Tere made with fresh tomato, chile, basil, and pecorino. For 32 years, the owner, chef and lady of the house, Donna Teresa, has run a tight ship—insisting that the food is consistently magnifico, and that her son, the manager, doesn’t misbehave (too much)._ (Via Panisperna 214; +39 06 482 5176)_






##### Capo Boi


Just because you’re eating like a local, that doesn’t mean it can’t be elegant. [Capo Boi](http://www.capoboi.net/) is a fish-centric, Sardinian-kitchen restaurant where dignified Romans go for special occasions. The precious neighborhood itself, Coppide, in between Parioli and Trieste, might as well be one of the secret ingredients on the restaurant’s no-miss menu, with its glamorous, high-status streets reminiscent of 1920’s Rome. The crudo fish appetizers, like the raw and smoked mussels and clams, are the best in town, as are the oysters, but save room for the entrees which are massive and sublime (I dream about the mixed grilled fish), but first comes the addictive Pane Carassua bread, otherwise known as “Italian music sheets” (this, because they’re so crispy and noisy, and there’s no stopping once you start). While dinner won’t come cheap, the white-linen experience is first class all the way. _(Via Arno, 80; +39 06 841 5535)_







**More on Rome:**



[Why You Should Skip the Colosseum (and the Vatican)](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/04/what-to-skip-in-rome-tourism-alternatives)







[The Yhi Wellness Spa, Gran Melia Rome Villa Agrippina](http://www.cntraveler.com/hot-list/2013/spas/yhi-wellness-spa-gran-meli-rome-villa-agrippina-italy)







[5 Hidden Attractions in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/03/rome-italy-hidden-secret-tourist-spots-churches-gardens-gelato)

pinterest.dek: Why settle for mediocre food at a touristy trattoria? Just an hour outside of Rome, you’ll find a culinary scene in Umbria that has all the foodies flocking.

items.title: LA FATTORIA
items.caption: The pretty, peach-colored albergo is known for its terrific hospitality and cozy accommodations, but its ristorante is where you’ll find the most beautiful antipasto plate in all of Umbria. Plates come piled high with prosciutto, paper-thin slivers of serrano ham, various cheeses, and buttery crostini topped with pesto, tomatoes, and truffle. According to La Fattoria’s co-owner, Lucille Buccioli, the restaurant has been serving the same kind of “timeless, traditional” food since the hotel—originally a farm—opened in 1975.

Thanks to its location in the lush, fertile Umbrian countryside, the restaurant is able to grow all its own organic produce. As a result, the ingredients in every dish served at La Fattoria come straight from its backyard—from the vegetables down to the olives cold-pressed for cooking. According to Buccioli, it was never about conforming to the now-popular farm-to-table or agriturism trends: “It’s just the way we have always done it. We grow it, and we cook it,” she explained. Consequently, most of the food on La Fattoria’s menu remains simple—this dish is just grilled radicchio with a balsamic drizzle—but due to the quality of its ingredients, remains strikingly delicious.

With the Umbrian countryside being rich in truffles, the ingredient is incorporated into most dishes. In this dish, black truffles are used to garnish a cheese-filled pastry. _Via Della Cava 32; +39 0743 53243; [lafattoriaspoleto.it](http://www.lafattoriaspoleto.it)_

items.title: IL TEMPIO DEL GUSTO
items.caption: We’ve already told you about [Il Tempio del Gusto’s cooking classes](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/06/learn-how-to-make-spaghetti-from-an-italian-chef). But the restaurant is primarily famous for its terrific pasta, made fresh daily by the renowned Chef Eros Patrizi. Here, Patrizi airs out a pasta sheet he will use to make this evening’s tortellini, one of the restaurant’s most popular dishes. Patrizi will spend up to three hours daily preparing pasta—most of which is hand-cut—for lunch and dinner.

Il Tempio del Gusto is also well-known for its contemporary take on authentic Italian dishes. Though this looks like beef tartare, it’s actually a tapas-like twist on the hearty _pappa al pomodoro_, a traditional tomato-and-bread soup eaten at room temperature. The dish consists only of tomatoes, bread, olive oil, and onion; it’s garnished with parsley and served as an apperitivo.

This dish, consisting of roasted guinea fowl served with potatoes and truffle, is another modern take on traditional Italian _cucina povera_, or “peasant cooking.” According to Chef Patrizi, beef is considered a luxury for many Umbrian farmers, so the meat generally used in everyday cooking is pork, poultry, or wild game such as boar or deer. _Via Arco di Druso 11; +39 0743 47121; [iltempiodelgusto.com](http://www.iltempiodelgusto.com/)_

items.title: PECCHIARDA TRATTORIA
items.caption: Unlike upscale, trendy Il Tempio, nearby Pecchiarda Trattoria serves hearty, unfussy down-home cooking with a smile. Chef Gianni Rivoli and his charming family run the rustic trattoria; you’ll always find them in the crowded courtyard in the summer, chatting with diners. “I came all the way from Terni for Gianni’s stringozzi!” A fellow diner told us over lunch. It’s no wonder—at Pecchiarda, you can score a bowl of delicious, handmade pasta for just 6€, and the house wine is as cheap as the water.

The _stringozzi al tartufo_—pasta with truffles—is the signature lunch dish at Pecchiarda. The dish itself is bare bones, the epitome of _cucina povera_, consisting only of pasta, olive oil, garlic, and truffles. It might not look like much on the plate, but don’t be fooled. Chef Gianni’s version is mind-blowingly good. _Vicolo S. Giovanni 1; +39 0743 221009; [ristorantepecchiarda.it](http://www.ristorantepecchiarda.it/)_

items.title: SOTTO LU FOCU
items.caption: Technically, Sotto Lu Foco is about thirty minutes outside Spoleto—but it's still considered by many locals as a favorite. With tables surrounding a blazing wood-fire oven, the eatery is perfect for cozy, cold-weather dining. Its food is decidedly rustic and unpretentious—plates of pecorino, prosciutto, steamed chicory, and salsicce are brought out for you to stuff into warm hunks of flatbread straight off the fire. Not into DIY–style dining? No worries. They’ll throw a pizza onto the fire for you, too, topped with anything your heart desires. _Piazza G. Verdi 4; +39 0744 931174_

pinterest.hed: Best Restaurants in Testaccio, Rome's Original Foodie Neighborhood
pinterest.dek: Here are the absolute must-visit foodie spots in Rome's Testaccio neighborhood, where Roman cuisine was born.
pinterest.seoTitle: Best Restaurants in Testaccio, Rome's Original Foodie Neighborhood
pinterest.seoDescription: Here are the absolute must-visit foodie spots in Rome's Testaccio neighborhood, where Roman cuisine was born.
pinterest.socialTitle: Best Restaurants in Testaccio, Rome's Original Foodie Neighborhood
pinterest.socialDescription: Here are the absolute must-visit foodie spots in Rome's Testaccio neighborhood, where Roman cuisine was born.

items.caption:
It’s happened to the best of us—indulging in what we think is authentic Italian cuisine only to find out that it’s simply a fancier, once-frozen version of it. That’s why we skipped the overrated tourist traps, hopped on an [Eating Italy Food Tour](http://www.eatingitalyfoodtours.com/), and headed straight to Testaccio, the original foodie neighborhood of Rome—birthplace of “cuisine romana” and dubbed by the locals as the “Heart of Rome.” Here are the absolute must-visit spots in the city, featuring the best and most authentic food in all of Rome. 

*Pictured: Pizza from Volpetti Più.*

__THE FOOD:__ Pizza  
__THE SPOT:__ [Volpetti Più](http://www.volpetti.com/804/Volpetti-Piu)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Alessandro Volta 8

This cafeteria-style *tavola calda* offers some of the best *pizza al taglio* (pizza by the slice) in the city. The classic pizza margherita is their specialty, and they were rated third best of the some 1,500 pizza restaurants in Rome, according to our Eating Italy guide.

__THE FOOD:__ Meats and cheese  
__THE SPOT:__ [Volpetti](http://www.volpetti.com/home)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Marmorata 47

Find the finest selection of meats, cheeses, and wine at Volpetti, the deli owned by the same family that operates Volpetti Più. When you enter the store, you’ll be faced with tons of prosciutto (some aged for more than 40 years), truffled pecorino, and some of the best salami (infused with *barolo* wine) in the city.
Tip: Don’t forget to ask for samples.

__THE FOOD:__ Fresh produce and light bites  
__THE SPOT:__ Testaccio Market  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Beniamino Franklin

The Testaccio open-air market has been serving fresh, in-season produce to residents of this working-class neighborhood for generations. Here, you can touch, feel, and taste some of the freshest produce in the city.

__THE FOOD:__ Cannoli  
__THE SPOT:__ [Dess’Art](http://www.dessart.it/DessArt/Dessart.html)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Inside the Testaccio Market 

Locals will tell you the following about authentic cannoli: Only buy them from a Sicilian, and never purchase them pre-filled. Cannoli should be filled right after you order, on the spot. These cinnamon-seasoned cannoli were filled with ricotta cream and dipped in crushed pistachios.

__THE FOOD:__ Pasta  
__THE SPOT:__ [Flavio al Velavevodetto](https://www.facebook.com/pages/Flavio-Al-Velavevodetto-Quartiere-Testaccio-Roma/239639276118423)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via di Monte Testaccio 97

Flavio al Velavevodetto is an award-winning restaurant built into the side of Monte Testaccio, an old dump site turned into grass-covered hill. Years ago, the Romans dug into it and created caves to house their wine. Over time, local families turned these old wine cellars into restaurants. During our food tour, we sampled three different signature Italian pastas:

1. *Amatriciana*: A traditional pasta dish with sauce made from *guanciale* (cured pork cheek), pecorino cheese, and tomato.
2. Carbonara: This hearty pasta dish is made with egg yolk, pecorino cheese, guanciale (cured pork cheek), and black pepper—never cream.
3. *Cacio e Pepe*: As the name suggests, this authentic minimalist pasta is simple and made with Pecorino Romano cheese (*cacio*) and fresh black pepper (*pepe*).

__THE FOOD:__ Gelato  
__THE SPOT:__ [Giolitti](http://www.giolitti.it/en)  
__THE LOCATION:__ Via Amerigo Vespucci 35

Don’t be fooled by the hundreds of fancy gelato shops across Rome—our guide let us know that 90% of them put stabilizers and food dye in their flavors. Giolitti is a bustling neighborhood bar serving up some of the city’s best gelato since 1914. This historic establishment is loved by the locals, thanks to the homemade, authentic gelato.

fields.name: Jinna Yang
fields.shortBio: Jinna Yang is a lifestyle photographer and the Founder/Creative Director of [Grease and Glamour](http://greaseandglamour.com/), a visual destination serving up endless travel inspiration.
fields.bio: In April 2013, lifestyle photographer Jinna Yang quit her full-time fashion job to travel the world. She started sharing stories of her adventures on [Grease and Glamour](http://greaseandglamour.com/), helping inspire others to live life with purpose and follow their dreams. Founded in 2012, Grease and Glamour quickly became a platform for endless inspiration, showcasing some of the world's most beautiful destinations. Jinna’s work has been featured in Time Magazine, CNN Travel, Yahoo, BBC World Radio, and hundreds of other media outlets around the world.

pinterest.body:
## Roma Nuova


[Maria Shollenbarger](http://www.cntraveler.com/contributors/maria-shollenbarger) uncovers an electrifying new scene in some of Rome's most happening neighborhoods.





[#image: /photos/53ea8846dd4d6a0b75ef68af]|||The view from the Hotel Eden|||

Few places on earth can trade as robustly in travel fantasy fulfillment as Rome. Grandeur and grit meet in its narrow, shade-dappled streets and in the patrician stretches of its piazzas. Its pearlescent light can tease a sacred beauty out of even the most profane, tourist-thronged scene, and its citizens can turn as banal an act as taking out the garbage into a master class in insouciant comportment (the word for which, incidentally, is _sprezzatura_—an inimitably Italian quality that Romans seem to have a corner on). Most inspiring of all, the appeal of the timeless and the electric draw of the now merge more dynamically here than in any other European city. Neighborhoods in the heart of town—the ones we thought we knew—have been reinvigorated with stylish hotels and boutiques. And as in places like London and New York, where the outer boroughs are the new centers of gravity, districts farther afield are being transformed by a creative group of chefs and shop owners. This is your guide to the city’s sweet spots, where tradition and innovation are in perfect balance.










## Centro Storico


Lots of people recognize the Via Giulia in photos, since it’s one of the most photogenic streets in Rome; probably not quite as many know it firsthand, tucked as it is into a curve of the Tiber, away from the more heavily trod reaches of the Centro Storico. Fewer still are familiar with its illustrious pedigree: The half-mile-long, ruler-straight stretch of _sanpietrini_ stones was constructed in 1508 by Donato Bramante, on the order of Pope Julius II, as one of Renaissance Rome’s first major urban-renewal projects. Lined with sixteenth- and seventeenth-century noble palaces and divided by an ivy-covered arch designed by Michelangelo, it passes through the ancient districts of Ponte and Regola. It is tranquil, beautiful, and seriously posh.

[#image: /photos/53ea8846dd4d6a0b75ef689f]|||_Pasta perfetta_ at the _salumeria_/wine bar Roscioli, in the Centro Storico.|||

It’s here that the architect Antonio Girardi has opened **D.O.M**, a 24-room hotel in a former Cla­re­tian monastery. The building’s exterior is typical Roman pastel-washed prettiness, but inside the palette is all whites, grays, and browns punctuated by rich linens and velvets, brass, and leather furniture. Beneath the coffered ceilings, the walls are inlaid with 400-year-old flagstones from the nearby Church of Santa Lucia del Gonfalone, installed in the nineteenth century and embossed with Latin liturgical exhortations commencing with _D.O.M_, the acronym for _Deo Optimo Maximo_ (“To God, most good, most great”).





The relative calm here belies an unbeatable central location. A hop to the south end of the street and a skip across the Ponte Sisto take you to the Piazza Trilussa, gateway to the humming bars and trendy boîtes of Trastevere. Some of Rome’s best shopping is on the neighboring Via dei Pellegrini, Via di Monserrato, and Via dei Banchi Vecchi, where **Laura Urbinati **sells her signature monochrome bikinis, which can be spotted on beaches from Gallipoli to Cap­albio. It’s a five-minute stroll to the genial chaos of the Campo dei Fiori and, five minutes beyond that, the Via dei Giubbonari, where you’ll find the beloved _salumeria_/­wine bar **Roscioli**. Everyone extols brothers Alessandro and Pierluigi Roscioli’s genius, from the prosciutto-studded bread to what has to be the city’s most faultless _cacio e pepe_. (Perhaps the thing it hasn’t perfected is amiable and refined service—but no one in Rome should expect that.) A takeout _baccalà_ sandwich wrapped in paper from **Dar Filettaro**—a block up from Roscioli, set back from the street in a tiny _piazzetta_—is a greasier, messier, but equally transporting affair.





[#image: /photos/53ea8846976f8f2d44d524a0]|||Antonio Girardi, architect and co-owner of the 24-room hotel D.O.M.|||

Between D.O.M and the Piazza Navona lies the Via del Governo Vecchio. This is Rome’s answer to New York’s Elizabeth Street in Nolita: home to independent boutiques and a couple of superlative vintage emporiums, where anyone with a hundred-odd euros and a serious inclination to dig can turn up gems like a ladies’ Belstaff motorcycle jacket circa 1974. The street’s appeal was enhanced with the arrival of jewelry designer **Delfina Delettrez**—daughter of Silvia Venturini Fendi—who opened her first boutique here in 2011. Delettrez’s totemic design motifs—evil eyes, skulls, jewel-­encrusted spiders, and attenuated bones recalling reliquaries—are as beautiful as they are provocative. Equally imaginative are the jewelry designs by Paolo Giacomelli and Roberta Paolucci at **Iosselliani R-01-IOS**, where the pieces incorporate brass and silver into chain mail or tribal feather motifs.

Just around the corner from Iosselliani is D.O.M’s primary competition. **J.K. Place Roma **is the third J.K. hotel from Florentine entrepreneur Ori Kafri. Its 30 rooms are a stylish retrofit of a former school, situated about halfway between the august angles of Richard Meier’s Ara Pacis Museum and the sceney Piazza San Lorenzo in Lucina. (**Ciampini**, at number 29 on the piazza, is your HQ here: perfect morning espresso stop; humming _aperitivo_ scene; best pistachio gelato in town; air-kissing all day.) The hotel’s flamboyant style favors neutrals doused with color (corridors are upholstered in turquoise and lime raw silk) and reproduction antiquities rubbing marble shoulders with mid-century designs. The hotel achieved cachet with the Roman _movida_ more or less from the day it opened; it’s an ideal place to feel at the center of things.









[#image: /photos/53ea8848976f8f2d44d524c2]||||||

Photographers Gentl & Hyers capture the electrifying new scene in some of Rome's most happening neighborhoods.





[read more](#)






## Monti


Wedged between the crumbling monoliths of the Imperial Fora and the staid government palaces of Quirinal Hill, the lemon-and-apricot facades lining Monti’s eighteenth-century streets are lovely, if not terrifically distinct from those in many other parts of town. Over the last several years, though, a new generation of adoptive Monticiani have given it an indie vibrancy that’s made it a destination in its own right. This is evident in the “kilometer-zero” mantra of** Urbana 47**, an industrial-chic space serving hyper-locally sourced meats and produce (an adjacent art-house movie theater, Cinema Urbana 47, made its debut in 2012). At **Aromaticus**, owners Luca De Marco and Francesca Lombardi bring culinary bona fides—they worked in Rome as the chef at Open Baladin and the sommelier at Open Colonna, respectively—to their bistro meets urban farming emporium. In addition to the potted herbs, designer trowels, and organic produce, there’s an excellent lunch menu of salads, cheese plates, and charcuterie to complement Luca’s sublime steak tartare. At the black-and-white-tiled **Gaudeo**, you’ll find the paradigm of the _paninoteca_: There are myriad combinations available, but stick to two or three ingredients in your panino (the turkey and Sardinian goat’s milk ricotta is a favorite) so that the quality of each really shines.







 Shop owners and designers likewise find Monti’s streets friendly to the trade of the quirky and the twice-loved (after the Via del Governo Vecchio, Monti has the city’s best vintage stores). The women’s fashion shop **B** stocks the often-monochromatic designs (the _B_ is for both _black and bianco_) of independent and established European labels, from Faliero Sarti pashminas to Céline trousers. At **DOP Concept Store**, Arabella Valdieri sources only a few pieces from niche labels to supplement her own small line of soft, deconstructed separates—whether you walk out with a kidskin clutch or a slim linen sundress, chances are you’ll be the only one back home with it. And of course, if it’s Saturday or Sunday, you’ll hit the **Mercato Monti**. What used to be a better-than-most flea market has evolved into a showcase of small purveyors selling handmade goods and first-rate vintage. On any given day, the mix might include 1950s jewelry, handmade leather sandals, and ’70s Gucci totes.










## Testaccio and Ostiense


Baroque domes, pastel frescoes, wisteria-draped _piazzette_: You’ll find none of the quintessential Roman sights in Testaccio and Ostiense, which abut each other along the silver-brown stretch of the Tiber below Trastevere. Dirt and industry are deeply embedded in their DNA: Testaccio’s late-nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century grid of middle-class apartment buildings rests on ancient Roman landfill, comprising tens of thousands of terra-cotta urns abandoned millennia ago after being off-loaded from ships bearing supplies from the imperial provinces. Ostiense’s skyline is characterized as much by steel bridges and graffitied warehouses as by the famous Pyramid of Cestius; its premier museum, the Centrale Montemartini, is housed in a decommissioned power station.







 But what these two neighborhoods lack in camera-readiness they make up for in genuine urban buzz—and for food lovers, they are Rome’s place to be. Make a pilgrimage to the **Testaccio Market**, which still retains its special Roman brand of industrious cacophony, to stock up on prosciutto, fresh chicory, and just about everything in between, with a side trip to the 150-year-old delicatessen **Volpetti**, a must for hand-cut pasta, anchovies in Sicilian olive oil, or any one of the seven different preparations of artichokes.





[#image: /photos/53ea8846976f8f2d44d524b0]|||A new gastro-hub in the Ostiense area|||

The new gastronomic nexus here is **Porto Fluviale**, a dining-drinking-snacking mecca spread across a 10,000-square-foot warehouse that was formerly part of the Magazzini Generali, Rome’s principal wholesale market. Now it’s a cavernous series of spaces finished with pale-brick walls, industrial work lamps, and reclaimed-wood shelves offering a staggering bounty of Italian _gastronomia_. There’s a bar that hums from late morning to the wee hours—the place for both a perfect espresso and a Campari spritz—along with a pizzeria centered around two massive wood ovens, one for thin-crust _pizze romane_, the other for the pillowy Neapolitan version. Elsewhere there’s a tapas bar, a patisserie/tearoom, and a lounge stocked with leather club chairs and chesterfield sofas.







 Due northeast of Porto Fluviale is the former Ostiense Air Terminal, home since June 2012 to **Eataly**, a four-story hymn to all that is superlative in Italian gastronomy and viticulture (it has a sister location in New York). The country’s finest chefs make regular guest appearances in its show kitchens, and some of its best-loved niche food specialists—Teo Musso for beer, Roberto Battaglia for _mozzarella di bufala_, Alessandro Frassica for panini, and Slow Food master Sergio Capaldo for meat—have dedicated premises here.














## Pigneto


-=-=-=-


__Watch__






 Information and inspiration.







 * _[**The Great Beauty**](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dyt430YkQn0)_



 Pado Sorrentino’s 2013 paean to Rome nightlife.




 * _[**Nights of Cabiria**](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HHSw7jxYCOk)_



 Federico Fellini’s 1957 classic.







__Read__






 * _**Four Seasons in Rome: On Twins, Insomnia, and the Biggest Funeral in the History of the World**_



 By Anthony Doerr (Scribner, $14).




 * _**Terroir Guides: Food Wine Rome**_



 By David Downie (Little Bookroom, $25).










People will tell you that Pigneto is Rome’s Brooklyn. Whether you consider this a selling point or not, there is undeniably something of that borough’s cool to be found along the Via del Pigneto, an _affiche_-plastered pedestrian stretch set north of the rusted train tracks radiating out from Termini Station. A Communist enclave in the early 1900s, then a dodgy area known for drugs and prostitution, Pigneto has spent the last few years getting fancied up—although you might still be treated to an authentic street brawl when dining alfresco at **Primo**. The restaurant is a stalwart of the Pigneto scene, a place where the lackadaisical service is offset by a few standout dishes, among them a heavenly fava puree topped with burrata. Primo’s Tricker’s-wearing owners also have the nearby **Rosti**, whose menu mixes _maremmana_-beef bur­gers and pastrami sandwiches with half a dozen _pizze bianche_ and a Sunday-afternoon _pasta al forno_ lunch.



It’s a magnet for the neighborhood’s creative classes and young parents, whose little ones gambol freely in its 7,500-square-foot garden strung with fairy lights. And you’d be remiss not to stop in at **Necci**, an institution since 1924; Pasolini famously filmed (and slummed) here in the early ’60s, and now its English co-owner, Benjamin Hirst, an alumnus of Fergus Henderson’s kitchen, has given it a shabby-cool makeover and a refined-rustic menu. Anytime between 8 a.m. and 1 a.m., seven days a week, is a good time to go, given that Necci morphs throughout the day from coffee-and-_cornetto_ pit stop to _aperitivo_ hot spot to serious _osteria_ turning out fresh takes on typical dishes, from artichokes to eel. The preponderance of whiskers and sockless brogues among the clientele may indeed suggest Brooklyn—but the flavors are unmistakably Rome.













 __Stay__










 [D.O.M Via Giulia](http://domhotelroma.com) 131; 39-06-683-2144; doubles from $545.







 [Hotel Eden Via Ludovisi](http://dorchestercollection.com) 49; 39-06-478-121; doubles from $321.







 [J.K. Place Roma Via di Monte d’Oro](http://jkroma.com) 30; 39-06-698- 2634; doubles from $820.






####

fields.name: Maria Shollenbarger
fields.shortBio: London-based contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Born and raised in Los Angeles and educated in New England and Italy, Maria Shollenbarger now calls East London home. She worked at *InStyle*and *Travel + Leisure,* among others, before joining *Condé Nast Traveler* in October 2013. She is the Travel Editor for *How To Spend It,* the luxury supplement to the Financial Times.

fields.bio:
Gentl & Hyers (Andrea Gentl and Martin Hyers) are a New York based photography team that met while studying photography at Parson's School of Design. They have been working together since 1993; photographing still life, food, beauty, fashion, interiors & travel for a wide array of editorial and advertising clients.
In addition to their commercial work, Martin is currently involved in an ongoing personal photography project with fellow photographer William Mebane. Their work can be seen at [Hyers and Mebane](http://www.hyersandmebane.com). Andrea is often shooting foragers, locavores and other things of interest & inspiration for her blog [Hungry Ghost Food and Travel ](http://www.hungryghostfoodandtravel.com)
They live in Downtown Manhattan with their two children Sam and Lula.

shop.hed: Shop Like a Real Roman at Magazzino Allo Statuto
shop.dek: The Magazzino allo Statuto, or MAS, department store in Rome boasts five floors of clothing, shoes, jewelry, luggage, and more. It's legendary among locals and is the perfect spot for amazing deals—as well as the authentic Roman shopping experience.
shop.seoTitle: Shop Like a Real Roman at Magazzino Allo Statuto
shop.seoDescription: The Magazzino allo Statuto, or MAS, department store in Rome boasts five floors of clothing, shoes, jewelry, luggage, and more. It's legendary among locals and is the perfect spot for amazing deals—as well as the authentic Roman shopping experience.
shop.socialTitle: Shop Like a Real Roman at Magazzino Allo Statuto
shop.socialDescription: The Magazzino allo Statuto, or MAS, department store in Rome boasts five floors of clothing, shoes, jewelry, luggage, and more. It's legendary among locals and is the perfect spot for amazing deals—as well as the authentic Roman shopping experience.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d98b6dec627b149dc4c7]||||||

Visiting Rome and looking for a cool souvenir to bring home? A Christmas present? Or just something nice for yourself? Forget the crowded, touristy Via Del Corso or Via Condotti. If you're after some genuinely cool, quirky all-Italian things at affordable prices, the fantastic Magazzino allo Statuto—otherwise known as the MAS department store—beckons from across town in Rome's Esquilino neighborhood.



MAS is something of an institution in Rome. Its five floors—filled with racks and piles of clothing, shoes, jewelry, luggage, toys, and more—are legendary among locals, who flock to the store regularly in search of fun, oddball treasures. (Lately, they've been flocking even more heavily, now that MAS is rumored to be closing in early 2014). The top three floors are dedicated entirely to clothing, all of which is made in Italy.





[#image: /photos/53d9d98bdcd5888e145a704c]||||||

On my last shopping trip, I picked up a cool Papa Francesco (Pope Francis) T-shirt for one euro, and some thick, plush winter tights for two euro. A friend of mine bought 20 pairs of wool trousers for ten euro flat. You can pick up cool hats for one euro, a pair of silk pajamas for only five euro. But it's not just the great stuff you'll emerge with, if you're patient. What I love most about this place is its atmosphere—sort of like a charming, cracked-out Century 21—and its diverse crowd, from nonnas, to bargain hunters, to savvy fashionistas in search of their next statement outfit. Every trip to MAS is an experience—one that you won't get visiting Rome's well-known shopping thoroughfares.







**More on Rome:**



[Rome's Coolest Food Markets: Mercato Esquilino](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/mercato-esquilino-rome-italy-market-guide)







[Eating Out in Rome: Where the Locals Go](http://www.cntraveler.com/food/2012/01/Rome-Restaurants-Local-Roman-Favorite-Dining-Spots)







[Rome's Iconic Hotel Eden Slated For Facelift](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/hotel-eden-rome-italy-renovation-092513)










Photos: Alyssa Shelasky

shop.hed: At This Roman Pastry Shop, the Packaging's As Delicious As the Pastry
shop.dek: Il Giglio Pasticceria, in Rome's quartiere San Lorenzo, is the Italian pastry shop that you've been searching for. It's cookies, tiramisu, cannoli and pasticciotto aren't just delicious and beautiful—their packaging is too.
shop.seoTitle: At This Roman Pastry Shop, the Packaging's As Delicious As the Pastry
shop.seoDescription: Il Giglio Pasticceria, in Rome's quartiere San Lorenzo, is the Italian pastry shop that you've been searching for. It's cookies, tiramisu, cannoli and pasticciotto aren't just delicious and beautiful—their packaging is too.
shop.socialTitle: At This Roman Pastry Shop, the Packaging's As Delicious As the Pastry
shop.socialDescription: Il Giglio Pasticceria, in Rome's quartiere San Lorenzo, is the Italian pastry shop that you've been searching for. It's cookies, tiramisu, cannoli and pasticciotto aren't just delicious and beautiful—their packaging is too.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d972dcd5888e145a6fa1]|||The pasticciotto at Il Giglio Pasticceria|||

We know why you're in Rome. Sure, there's the [Colosseum](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/04/what-to-skip-in-rome-tourism-alternatives) and the [Vatican](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/04/what-to-skip-in-rome-tourism-alternatives) and all its [other fine attractions](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/03/rome-italy-hidden-secret-tourist-spots-churches-gardens-gelato), but we know what you really want. You want cannoli. _You want tiramisu._ Don't get us wrong, there's no judgement here: in fact, we have just the place for you.



Il Giglio Pasticceria, in Rome's quartiere San Lorenzo, is the Italian pastry shop that you've been searching for. It's not in the guidebooks, they don't have a website, and the Italians want it that way. Locals start lining up for coronets and cappuccinos every day at 5 a.m. without fail. You'll find yourself waiting a while if you saunter in at a reasonable morning hour (say, for a 9 a.m. breakfast pastry), so I'd suggest a midday treat. All their cannolis, tiramisu, cookies and cakes are excellent, but I always go for the pasticciotto with ricotta or nutella filling (pictured above). It doesn't look fancy—rather like a dry mound of pie crust, really—but it is the world's most divine Pop-Tart.

[#image: /photos/53d9d9726dec627b149dc3dc]||||||

But wait—there's more. It's not just the perfect Italian pastries that draw hordes of locals to Il Giglio, that's just half of it. Another huge draw is the pride and care that owner Vincenzo Di Pasquale puts into the packaging of your delicious treat. Even if you get one small cookie, he'll never just throw it into a brown paper bag or nondescript bakery box. No, Di Pasquale will gently and lovingly wrap your sweet into an elegant, paper-wrapped package, held together by gold curling ribbon. It's like walking away with a birthday present, every single time. _Viale Ippocrate 144; +39 06 4462000_






**More on Rome:**



[To See the Real Rome, Visit Mercato Esquilino](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/mercato-esquilino-rome-italy-market-guide)







[When in Rome: Eat Here](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/locals-favorites-restaurants-rome)







[A Hidden Gelato Shop in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/03/pinterest-photo-gelateria-del-teatro-rome-italy)










Photos by Alyssa Shelasky

shop.hed: To See the Real Rome, Visit Mercato Esquilino
shop.dek: If you want a taste of the real Rome, you can't miss this place. Mercato Esquilino—the Esquilino Markets—offer a colorful slice of Rome's bustling immigrant community. Enjoy the market's fresh, diverse international produce and rich, colorful history.
shop.seoTitle: To See the Real Rome, Visit Mercato Esquilino
shop.seoDescription: If you want a taste of the real Rome, you can't miss this place. Mercato Esquilino—the Esquilino Markets—offer a colorful slice of Rome's bustling immigrant community. Enjoy the market's fresh, diverse international produce and rich, colorful history.
shop.socialTitle: To See the Real Rome, Visit Mercato Esquilino
shop.socialDescription: If you want a taste of the real Rome, you can't miss this place. Mercato Esquilino—the Esquilino Markets—offer a colorful slice of Rome's bustling immigrant community. Enjoy the market's fresh, diverse international produce and rich, colorful history.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d98e6dec627b149dc4ed]||||||

If you want a taste of the real Rome—and you've already dined at these [fine local establishments](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/locals-favorites-restaurants-rome)—then you can't miss the Mercato Esquilino. No really. Love culture? You'll enjoy the market's rich and colorful history. Major foodie? You'll swoon over the market's fresh and diverse international produce—perfect for throwing together an impromptu picninc.



Don't be deterred by the battered industrial building in which the market is housed. Just venture into the noisy, souk-like jumble of stalls and lose yourself in displays of fresh greens, meats, cheeses, and fish. The variety of fruits and nuts is impressive, and the prices are surprisingly reasonable (I once left with bags upon bags of cherries, plantains, hazelnuts, dates, and dried apricots—all for less than 10 euros).



If you don't want to shop, that's fine too. Spend your afternoon sampling the array of unpronounceable delicacies and sniffing fragrant spices and herbs from every international cuisine imaginable, from tagines to pho to pasta e fagioli.







Here’s what I found at Mercato Esquilino this week (tip: go early!), amid the nonnas and gourmands…








[#image: /photos/53d9d98edcd5888e145a7062]||||||

Fresh Filipino ingredients—sitaw (green string beans) and ampalaya (bitter melon)—can be used to make Filipino dishes like ginisang ampalaya (sautéed bitter melon) or pinakbet (mixed vegetables steamed in fish sauce).





[#image: /photos/53d9d98edcd5888e145a7060]||||||

****Grains, nuts and spices. Even if you're not planning to purchase any, the variety of these will surely impress you.





[#image: /photos/53d9d98e6dec627b149dc4dd]||||||

The fish sold here must be incredibly fresh because crowds of ladies haggle over it every morning—this morning was no exception. (They always win).





**More on Rome:**



[The Roman Eateries Tourists Don't Know About](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/locals-favorites-restaurants-rome)







[Why You Should Skip the Colosseum](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/04/what-to-skip-in-rome-tourism-alternatives)







[5 Secret Attractions in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/03/rome-italy-hidden-secret-tourist-spots-churches-gardens-gelato)








Photos by Alyssa Shelasky

featuredStays.name: Hotel de Russie
featuredStays.description: This contemporary hotel is in an ideal spot—between the Spanish Steps and the Piazza del Popolo—in a building that was formerly the headquarters of the Italian TV company RAI. Rooms in pastel tones overlook a stunning courtyard garden or the city’s terra-cotta roofs and the three top-floor suites come with private terraces. Dine on risotto pescatora or Mediterranean lobster with eggplant at Le Jardin de Russie, where summertime meals are taken in the garden. Sip a warm tea infusion or a fresh non-alcoholic cocktail at the spa and health club, equipped with a whirlpool, sauna, Turkish steam bath, and more.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Great service, attention to detail, and a lovely courtyard distinguish this perfectly placed hotel.

featuredStays.name: Hotel Donna Camilla Savelli
featuredStays.description: This restored sixteenth-century monastery in Trastevere was designed by one of the great Baroque architects, Francesco Borromini, and has all the play of convex and concave shapes for which the architect is celebrated: tall archways decorated in bas-relief in the bar area and a refectory complete with a lofty coffered ceiling, dark boiserie, and a pulpit where matins were read. The 78 rooms are soberly done (although the beds are sumptuous), with many of the convent’s antiques and Baroque architectural flourishes. The garden cloister, with its magnolia tree, camellias, jasmine, rooftop terrace, and smaller Cloister of the Angel, provides outdoor space where guests can enjoy the monastic tranquillity. What saves the property from too much gravitas is the hospitality of the exceptional staff.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Enjoy soaring archways and Baroque flourishes, courtesy of architect Francesco Borromini.

featuredStays.name: DOM
featuredStays.description: The dark, velvet-lined bar and narrow restaurant might not be to all tastes, but the location is the selling point here. Not to mention the rooms, which are sumptuous and light-filled—studies in opulent silks and linens, brass and stone—and the roof terrace, which affords quite a horizon: the rosy dome of the Vatican, the Juniculum, and the myriad terraces of the *centro storico.*
featuredStays.shortDescription: An unbeatable location, with a roof terrace offering sweeping views of the Vatican.

fields.caption: The lounge at **D.O.M** is one of a number of spots for a nice cocktail in Rome

featuredStays.name: The First Luxury Art Hotel
featuredStays.description: Twenty-nine rooms in a superbly renovated nineteenth-century building on a quiet street not far from the Tiber. Rooms are distributed around a light-flooded central atrium with white wrought-iron balustrades. Communal spaces are rigorously black-and-white; contemporary paintings and sculptures add splashes of color and wit.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Modern art meets 19th century architecture at this well-renovated spot in Rome’s historic center.
